loans.name: Necifora

texts.en:
Necifora M. is from Gingoog City. She is 56 years old, is married, and has three adult children.

Necifora owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Necifora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell.

Necifora is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sophary

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophary P. is 34 years old and her husband, Mr. Bo Rous, is 35 years old. They have been married since 1994 and have two children: one son and one daughter, both of them still young. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number One about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Her husband has full-time employment.

Sophary has been running a grocery store in her village for ten years. She is requesting her first loan of $600 to remodel her grocery store.

loans.use: To remodel her grocery store

Rene owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling coconut sap and also processing coconut wine, a traditional red wine locally known as "tuba" in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Rene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding his business. Rene is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new tools and containers for storage of coconut wine. This loan will be his 3rd from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family’s income. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Rorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Rorn S., shown on the right of the photo with her sister, is age 39 and is single. She lives with her sister and mother in a small village along National Road Number One about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Rorn has been selling pickled cucumbers for ten years.

The house where Rorn lives is old and one part is broken down. She wants to repair it, but she does not have money. Hence she is asking for a loan of $1,000 to make the repairs.

loans.use: To repair the house where she lives

loans.name: Joschua Alberto

texts.pt:
Jochua Alberto N., nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha vizinho com o Reino da Suazilândia, Província do Maputo, tem 31 anos de idade vive maritalmente é pai de uma filha de 2 anos não vai a escola. Fez a 9ª classe não continuou devido ao trabalho que não lhe permitia. Vive numa casa alugada com sua família e sustenta sua sobrinha que vive com ele em sua casa.

Nunca saiu da cidade natal, estudou e juntou se com sua esposa em Namaacha. Tem um emprego a mais de 15 anos no hotel libombos como servente de mesa trabalhando das 7h as 15h no período da manhã e das 15h as 23h no período da tarde auferindo 3.500.00mt que aplica nas despesas da casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancaria pois conta com ajuda da sua esposa que é funcionaria das águas de Namaacha.  


Nunca teve empréstimos em outros Bancos, conhece a Hluvuku-Adsema através dos seus colegas que são clientes da instituição. Este é o primeiro empréstimo de Jochua na Hluvuku e Kiva com qual pretende legalizar seu próprio terreno. Compromete se a pagar o empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos e dar inicio da sua própria casa e sair da casa de aluguer.
texts.en:
Jochua Alberto N. was born in Namaacha, near Suazilandia, in Maputo Province, Mozambique. He is 31 year old and lives with his wife and 2 year old daughter who doesn't go to school yet. He finished 9th grade but had to drop school to start working. He lives in a rented house with his wife and daughter plus a niece that lives with them. He never left his hometown, and he has been working for the past 15 years at Hotel Libombos as a waiter daily either from 7AM to 3PM or from 3PM TO 11PM, and he makes around U$100 per month, that he uses to support his family and tries to save, since his wife works too. He never had loans with other banks and he's asking for U$450, which she will use to try to get himself a piece of land. He's committed to pay that loan back so he can ask for more in the future and start building his house, so he won't need to rent any longer.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a piece of land

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophat C. is 26 years old and her husband, Mr. Neanghuy Sreng (they are pictured together), is 35 years old. They have been married since 2007 and just have one young son. They live along National Road Number One about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sophat and her husband have been farming since they married. They grow vegetables on their farmland in the village.

Sophat does not have her own motorcycle for commuting; she spends a lot of money for traveling costs very often. Therefore, she is applying for her first loan of $500 to purchase a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Veneranda

texts.en: Veneranda A. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 56 years old, is widowed, and has three adult children. Veneranda owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snack foods like banana-que (deep-fried banana covered with caramelized brown sugar) and fried banana in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Veneranda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. Veneranda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more bananas to cook, which subsequently will give her more income. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas to cook and sell

loans.name: Savin

texts.en:
Mrs. Savin P. and her husband, Mr. Yoin Meas, live on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1997 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of the children are in school and one is still young.

Savin has been a silk weaver for more than nine years. Besides weaving, she also started a new business selling finished silk fabric. She buys some of the finished silk fabric from the weavers in her village and transports it to sell in other provinces far away from her house.

Savin hopes to expand her new business so that she will be able to earn much more income to better support her family. So she is requesting a loan of $200 to purchase additional finished silk fabrics to sell.

loans.use: To purchase additional finished silk fabrics to sell

Sarin has been a mason for sixteen years while his wife has been selling fruit in Phnom Penh market for one year. He is asking for his first loan of $300 to purchase a motorcycle for commuting to work.

loans.name: Samnang

texts.en:
Mr. Samnang B. (pictured above) and his wife, Mrs. Chanthorn Mob, live in a small village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, across the Mekong River. They were married in 1990 and have five children: four sons and one daughter. 

Samnang has been a mason for more than sixteen years and he does this work in the village and nearby provinces. His wife has just started a business selling vegetables. 

Samnang has requested a loan of US $600. He will use $500 of the loan to purchase a motorcycle for commuting and he also will use $100 of the loan to build a kitchen.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Berlina

texts.en:

The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling bananas in the local community. Berlina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Berlina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Berlina is requesting her first loan, for 5000 PHP, which will be used to expand the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Berlina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Dembe Womens Group, Jinja

texts.en:
41-year-old K. Medi has been a taxi driver for an amazing twenty-three years. This married father of seven school-going children has been relying on the remuneration from this trade to bring food to his family’s table.

In the Jinja taxi park area where Medi has been operating from for all these years, his reputation and track record are never in question. By all accounts, he is a man with a friendly line of conduct, going by the way he associates with his fellow drivers.

Medi began as an apprentice taxi conductor, bidding his time slowly till he learnt how to drive and eventually become a driver. His desire to learn is part of the reason why he has seen such business longevity. Every month, he says he makes close to 240,000 shillings as profits.

With this loan, Medi says he wants to buy new tires for his taxi.

loans.use: To purchase new tires for his taxi

loans.name: Som

texts.en:
Mrs. R. is an older woman whose husband appears in the right of the photo. She is the mother of nine children, six of whom are now married and have already started new homes, while the remaining three are single. To help be responsible for family, two of her children are employed: one is a furniture decorator and the other sews clothes in the garment industry. 

R. has been engaged in a business selling food for years. She sells the food to laborers who work in the factory. She has a life partner in her husband who assists with her in the business activity. Presently, R. always hires a motor-taxi to deliver any ingredients for cooking food. Right now she hopes to cut down the fee of hiring taxi through using a loan she has requested to purchase a new motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Violeta Lucas

texts.pt:
Violeta Lucas G. nasceu na província de Inhambane, sul de moçambique, tem 49 anos de idade estudou ate a 12ª classe, não deu mas continuidade devido a falta de tempo, não tem filho pois é estéril, vive na casa cedida pelo serviço. Responsabiliza se pela sua mãe e sobrinho que vivem em inhambane enviando lhes em cada 3 meses uma sexta básica no valor de 1.000.00mt.  

Violeta ganha uma bolsa de estudos para Alemanha antiga RDA, onde fez uma formação profissional de dactilografia. Apois a Independência ela volta novamente a sua terra natal Moçambique concretamente em Inhambane, mas devido a falta de emprego saiu de Inhambane para província de Maputo no distrito de Namaacha na Fronteira da Suazilândia com sua tia. Esta consegue arranjar um emprego na Escola Secundária da Namaacha como dactilógrafa onde trabalha a mais de 16 anos das 7:30 as 15:30h auferindo mensalmente 2.960.84mt que aplica nas despesas da sua casa.com os empréstimos anteriores de (5.000.00mt, 8.000.00mt) não conseguiu concluir a sua obra devido ao elevado custo do material.

Este é o terceiro empréstimo de Violeta na Hluvuku e segundo com Kiva. O primeiro de 5000,00mt foi usado para compra de material de construção, o segundo de 8.000.00mt foi também usado para comprar material de construção e este terceiro de 15.000.00mt para a compra de material de construcao (cimento, areia, ferro e outros)para continuar com sua obra. Esta confiante que vai pagar cem nenhum problema e pedir um novo empréstimo para fazer manutenção da sua casa.
texts.en:
Violeta Lucas G. was born in Inhambane, south of Mozambique. She is 49 and studied until 12th grade, but had to drop school because she didn't have time. She doesn't have children and lives in a house given her by her job. She also helps her mother and a nephew that lie in Inhambane by sending them some basic food products every 3 months. Violeta had a scholarship and studied in Germany back in the day, where she became a certified typist. After the independence she went back to her native Mozambique and moves to Maputo in Namaacha District, to live with an aunt. She then got a job as a typist at a local school where she's been working for the past 16 yeras from 7:30AM to 3:30PM, making around U$90 per month. This is her third loan with Hluvuku and her second with Kiva. The frist two were used to buy construction supplies. She is asking for U$450 so she can buy more materials she needs like cement, iron and rocks, and finishe building her house. She's confident she will pay it back on time and hopes to ask for another loan after this one is paid so she can do some maintenance in her house.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction supplies

loans.name: Senecita

texts.en:
Senecita M. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 47 years old. Senecita is single and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Senecita owns a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing Video Karaoke services to local community members. Senecita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Senecita joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Senecita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to expand the business. Senecita is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase items such as additional chairs and tables for her customers. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Senecita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Toir

texts.en:
Toir is a 54 year old, married father of 5 children. Toir owns a grocery store and provides for his family with the revenue generated by the grocery store. He is requesting a loan of $2700 US Dollars to increase his stock. Toir is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once and awhile to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. One of his dreams is that his children will progress by means of their studies.  He believes his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.     

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing foodstuffs to increase the range of goods for sale

loans.name: Mpungwe Aliseeka Group Of Jinja

texts.en:
B. Hasifa’s face lights up with buoyancy when asked about her current prospects in her ten-year-old maize-selling business in Mpungwe, Jinja. With her lucrative business, this vastly experienced businesswoman has been able to substantially provide for all her six children’s needs, especially their education.

Different school head-teachers in Jinja have been flocking to her work station to buy her maize product which she stores in plenty after the harvest season. Since she began, she has been making steady profits in the range of 200,000 to 250,000 shillings per week.

With the hard work ethic she embodies, Hasifa’s future business prospects are looking favorable every passing year. This being her first loan, she is gleefully optimistic that it will be invaluable in helping her buy more bags of maize.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of maize to restock her graneries

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marta Cahavela

texts.pt:
Marta chavela D. N. nasceu em Changalane, uma Localidade que dista 38km do Distrito da Namaacha, situado na Província de Maputo Tem 41 anos de idade é mãe de 3 filhos com idades compreendiD. entre os 6 aos 19 anos de idade.todos eles encontram se a estudar. Vive na casa própria com sua família e responsabiliza se pela sua mãe enviando lhe 1.000.00mt por mês.

Marta é proprietária de um trator inicia com trabalhos de lavoura nas machambas onde conseguiu juntar um fundo para dar início do seu negócio, anos depois houve um conflito entre familiares na disputa de bens do seu falecido sogro e ela fica na beira da falência. Numa conversa com sua prima que é nossa cliente fala lhe acerca dos nossos serviços e ela aproxima se solicitando um empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt para reforçar o seu negocio. Ela consegue levar avante o negócio, tem viajado uma vez por mês devido a localização da sua loja que se encontra perto da fronteira e a maior parte dos consumidores fazem as compras na vizinha Suazilândia, ela tem como melhor produto (açúcar, arroz e bebiD.). Consegue de lucro um valor de 6.000.00mt e ainda poupa 1.500.00mt. Conta com ajuda do seu esposo que é criador e proprietário de 32 cabeças de gado bovino.


Este é o terceiro empréstimo de Marta na Hluvuku e segundo com Kiva. O primeiro de 10.000.00mt usou para reforçar o seu negócio pois encontrava se na beira da falência, O segundo de 20.000.00mt foi usado para aumentar o volume do seu stock e conseguiu com o empréstimo adquirir uma viatura que lhe facilita nos seus trabalhos diários. Este terceiro de 20.000.00mt pretende comprar produtos(acucar, arroz, farinha, bebiD. e outros)para aumentar a sua mercadoria. Esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para expandir mais ainda o seu negocio e vender a grosso.
texts.en:
Marta chavela D. N. was born in Changalane, a town about 38km from Namaacha, Maputo Province, Mozambique. She is 41 years old and has 3 children with ages between 6 and 19, all of them students. She lives with her own house with her family and also helps her mother by sending her U$90 every month. Marta owns a grocery store. In previous days she owned a tractor and worked in the farms where she was able to save some money to start her own business; later on there was some family dispute over her late father-in-law's properties, and she ended up declaring bankrupcy. She heard of Kiva from a cousin and she's asking for a U$600 loan, which she will use to improve her business. She travels once a month to get more products for her store, and her best selling products are sugar, rice and beverages. She makes about U$175 per month and she's been able to save U$40 every month. She counts with the help of her husband who own 32 cows. This is Marta's third loan and she's using it to buy more merchandise like sugar, rice, flour, beverages and others, so she can sell more and have more profit. She's confident she will be able to pay the loan back before the deadline, and ask for a new loan to expand even more her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food products for reselling

loans.name: Balitwegomba Women's Group, Jinja

texts.en:
Ten years ago, 30-year-old M. Juliet was like any other naïve business upstart. Being in two minds did not help either, as she was on the one hand being dissuaded from trying her hand at any other business, whilst her close consorts were constantly prevailing upon her to start a retail shop.

With huge reserves of courage and conviction in tow, Juliet, in the midst of all this, made up her mind to start a retail shop in Buwenge, Jinja. She decided to dispense with the soft drink business she had all along banked on as her main source of livelihood.

Juliet’s hard work ethic spawned an unprecedented growth in her business profits. As her niche grew, so did the profits accruing to her business. In a week, she reveals her business generates 500,000 Ugandan shillings. With this income, this married lady has gotten into a steady stride in terms of fully providing for all her four children. Juliet has also been eking out supplementary profits from her poultry and commercial motorcycle businesses.

With this loan, Juliet wants to rejuvenate her retail shop with more merchandise like sugar, soap, bags of rice, etc.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items for her store like sugar, salt, rice and soap

loans.name: Azam

texts.en:
Azam Y., 36, owns a little grocery store in the local market where he sells a variety of goods. He works together with his brothers. Azam, together with his wife, have 3 children to support. Azam has asked for a loan of $1400 USD to purchase more grocery products, allowing him to expand his options and increase his inventory. He believes that this will allow him to reach a wider customer base so he can increase his income to help provide for his family. Azam looks forward to seeing the results of this investment and hopes that his family can become more economically secure for the future. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing foodstuffs to increase the range of goods to sell

loans.name: Lucina

texts.en:
Lucina Y. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 39 years old. Lucina is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Lucina runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Lucina has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lucina joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Lucina is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Lucina from HSPFI. She plans to use the resulting revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Elisa Bembene

texts.pt:
Elisa Bembene G. nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha, Província do Maputo, vizinho com o reino da Suazilândia tem 41 anos de idade é separada, mãe de 2 filhos de 12 e 14 anos de idade, ambos vão a escola. Fez a 6ª classe não continuou devido a sua ida ao lar, vive na casa dos seus pais e responsabiliza se por eles.



Nunca saiu do Distrito, iniciou sua atividade de criação quando separa se do seu marido. Hoje tem um negócio próprio de criação de pintos onde tem criado em fases no intervalo de 20 a 20 dias sendo 3 caixas em cada fase e tendo de lucro um valor de 3.000.00mt que aplica nas despesas da casa e da sua obra o que não lhe tem sido fácil por essa razão então aproxima se a Hluvuku e Kiva solicitando um empréstimo para aumentar o volume da sua criação.


Nunca teve empréstimos em outros Bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através da sua vizinha que também e cliente desta instituição. Este é o primeiro empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com qual pretende comprar pintos para criação e revenda, esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto e pedir outro empréstimo para ampliar sua capoeira.
texts.en:
Elisa Bembene G. was born in the District of Namaacha, Maputo Province, which neighbors the kingdom of Swaziland. She is 41 years old and separated. She has two children ages 12 and 14 who attend school. She attended school until the 6th grade but did not finish because she left home. She lives in her parents' home and supports them. She has never left Namaacha. She began farming when she separated from her husband. Today she has her own business raising chickens. She has raised them in intervals of 20 days with 3 boxes in every phase, and a profit of 3,000.00MT which she uses for household expenses and to constructing her home, which has not been easy. For this reason she has come to Hluvuku and Kiva to request a loan to increase her number of chickens. She has never had loans in other Banks. She learned about Hluvuku through her neighbor who is also a client. This is her first loan, in the amount of 10.000.00MT which she plans to use to purchase chicks to raise and resell. She is confident that she will pay her loan off early and request another loan to enlarge her hen house.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of chicks to raise and resell

loans.name: Bin

texts.en:
Bin R. is 55 years old and a resident of Kompong Tom Province, where she has owned a plot of land since 1995. She grows rice crops, which she plants twice a year. She is widowed and the mother of three children; one is married and lives away from the family home, and two are single and work in different jobs. 

Bin R. is a hard-working woman who never wastes time in order to earn money to ensure that the family has a better life. Bin R. faces an obstacle: the house she lives in is too small for them. She dreams of having another house for her family members to live in, but she has not enough money to fulfill her dream. Therefore, Bin R. decided to ask for a loan on Kiva to add to the cash she has saved up in order to buy land which includes a wooden house.

loans.use: To buy land which includes a wooden house

texts.en:

Family effort has been the key to his business's growth since everyone collaborates and now, he has a steady customer base due to the quality of his products. 

Currently, Ilhom is seeking a loan of $1500 USD that he wishes to spend on expanding his business, which will allow them to offer better services. Be a part of this family's achievements. They sincerely thank you for your support.

loans.name: Alberto Miomo

texts.pt:
Alberto Miomo C. nasceu em Gaza, Provincia de Maputo, Sul de Moçambique tem 63 anos de idade casado e pai de 7 filhos, com idades compreendidas entre os 10 aos 40 anos de idade. Somente os três mais novos é que se encontram a estudar. Fez a 6ª classe do antigo sistema não continuou devido a falta de condições.vive na casa própria com sua família e não responsabiliza se por ninguem

Alberto consegue arranjar um emprego como estivador braçal e devido a sua dedicação e força de vontade é promovido para gerente do STIVA durante 20 anos auferia mensalmente um valor de 25.000.00mt, mas quando ele é avisado acerca da sua reforma constrói de imediato uma barraca em sua casa. Hoje ele é reformado e aufere um valor mensal de 8.500.00mt o que não satisfaz as sua necessidades então numa conversa com a sua esposa que é nossa cliente fala acerca dos nossos serviços aproximou se solicitando um empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt para reforçar o seu negócio. O impacto da sua atividade é notório pois fornece produtos básicos a comunidade reduzindo distâncias anteriormente percorridas em busca do mesmo serviço. Tem viajado uma vez por semana pois é único com barraca e porque também tem facilidade de transporte, tem tido de lucro 2.500.00mt e consegue poupar 1.000.00mt pois irão ajudar muito nos momentos críticos do seu negócio.

Este é o segundo empréstimo de Alberto na Hluvuku e Kiva, no valor de 15.000.00mt com qual pretende comprar produtos para sua barraca (amendoim, feijão, sardinha, massas) o anterior de 15.000.00mt foi usado para aumentar o volume do seu negócio, esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um outro para dar inicio a criação de frangos.
texts.en:
Alberto Miomo C. was born in Gaza, Maputo Province in southern Mozambique. He is 63 years old, is married, and has seven children between the ages of 10 and 40. Only the three youngest attend school. Alberto finished sixth grade in the old educational system; he did not continue because of financial difficulties. He lives in his own house with his family and does not support anyone else. Alberto found work as a cargo loader for STIVA, and because of his dedication and willpower he was promoted to manager. He worked there for 20 years, receiving 25,000 meticais monthly, but when he was informed that he would be retiring he immediately built a market stall in his house. Today he is retired and receives 8,5000 meticais monthly, which does not meet his needs. He spoke with his wife, who is a customer of Hluvuku, about our services and approached us to request a loan of 15,000 meticais to stock his business. His business is important because he supplies basic products to the community, reducing the distances people used to have to travel for the same items. Alberto travels once a week because he is the only one with a market stall and because he also has transportation. He makes 2,500 meticais in profits and manages to save 1,000 meticais, which will help greatly in tough times for his business. This is Alberto's second loan with Hluvuku and Kiva. With this 15,000 meticais loan, he intends to buy products for his stall (peanuts, beans, sardines, pasta). The previous 15,000 meticais loan was used to increase his inventory. He is confident that he will pay off the loan ahead of schedule and ask for another loan to begin raising chickens.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of peanuts, beans, sardines, pasta

loans.name: Kyarutanga Twetungura, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Putting up his hand at the extreme left is A. John Baptist. He is a hardworking and an ever-optimistic 35-year-old married father of five children aged between 15 and 8 years.

John Baptist operates a growing produce and retail business in Bwera, Ibanda, dealing in general merchandise such as soap, matches, soft drinks, beer, salt, sugar and cereals. With a business longevity of twelve years, he has managed to significantly sustain and improve his family’s welfare.

To all appearances, John Baptist’s future business prospects look rosy with close to 240,000 Ugandan shillings coming in monthly from his business. He envisions an even greater profit as he gets this loan, anticipating being in a position to buy more merchandise for his business. This will enable him to expand his business and also enable him to earn more revenue.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for his business

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en: Mrs. S., 26, has a job cultivating rice and vegetable crops for a profit, while her husband works with her on the farm. This couple got married some years ago, but they have no children yet. S. currently plants mushrooms which she will harvest and sell when they mature. S. will be using her first loan from Kiva to buy a small place where she will grow crops for extra income.

loans.use: To buy a small place where she will grow crops for extra income

loans.name: Milo Luis

texts.pt:
Milo Luis B. nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha Namaacha, na Fronteira da Suazilândia a Oeste da Província de Maputo, tem 25 anos de idade, é solteiro trabalhador e cem nenhum filho. Estudou ate a 10ª classe e teve que interromper para se formar num curso básico da P.R.M.vive na casa da mãe e responsabiliza se por ela.

 Milo formou se num curso básico da (P.R.M) polícia da república de Moçambique durante um ano, apos terminar o curso é afeto no Ministério do Interior como guarda central. E trabalhador a mais de 5 anos e aufere um valor mensal de 3.000.00mt,anos depois seu pai perde a vida, ele indemnizado e abre um negócio para ajudar nas despesas da casa para aumentar a renda familiar, aproxima se a Hluvuku solicitando o empréstimo para aumentar o stock de produtos. Tem como melhor produto o álcool nomeadamente (2M, vinho e whisk em calce), tem comprado semanalmente 20cx de 2M cada a 248, 10cx de vinho cada a 450, e 3cx de whisk cada a 900 e revendendo a 330, a 1200 e o Whisk a 25 cada calce na razão de 30 calce por garrafa consecutivamente, obtêm de lucro 6.000.00mt mensalmente e conta com ajuda de um empregado que recebe 1.500.00mt, por mês consegue e poupar na sua conta bancaria 1.500,00mt. 


Já teve empréstimos em outra instituição e decidiu não continuar devido a distância. Este é o segundo empréstimo de Milo na Hluvuku e Kiva.O primeiro de 10.000.00mt foi usado para aumentar o volume dos produtos, estes 15.000.00mt Serão usados para a mesma finalidade com objetivo de satisfazer a necessidade dos seus clientes, esta convencido que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para dar início da sua obra.
texts.en:
Milo Luis B. was born in the District of Namaacha, on the border with Swaziland in the western part of the Provicince of Maputo. He is 25 years old, and is a single worker, with no children. He attend school through the 10th grade and had to stop to enroll in a basic course of the PRM (Republic of Mozambique Police) He lives in his mother's home and supports her. Milo completed a one-year basic course with the (PRM) Republic of Mozambique Police. After he completed the course he was hired by the Ministry of the Interior as a central guard. He has been working for over 5 years and makes 3.000.00MT monthly. Years after his father died, he received a payout and opened a business to help with the household expenses and increase the family income. He approached Hluvuku requesting a loan to increase the stock of products. His best selling product is alcohol namely 2M (beer), wine and servings of whisky. Each week he purchases 20 boxes of 2M for 248 each, 10 boxes of wine at 450 each, and 3 boxes of whisky at 900 each. He resells them for 330, 1200, and whiskey at 25 per serving, with 30 servings per bottle, respectively. He makes 6.000.00mt per month and has the help of one employee who is paid 1.500.00MT monthly. He saves 1.500.00MT per month in his bank account. He has already had loans through another institution but decided not to continue with them due to the distance. This is Milo's second loan with Hluvuku and Kiva. The first was for 10.000.00MT which was used to increase his volume of products. These 15.000.00MT will be used for the same purpose, with the goal of meeting his customers' needs. He is confident that he will pay off the loan before it is due and request another loan to begin building his home.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase products (alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, etc.)

loans.name: Yassin

texts.en:
Yassin is a 55-year-old Lebanese entrepreneur and the father of five children. In 1985, he decided to open a grocery store in his town. He decided to open his shop because he saw a need for such services in the region, and also because he has experience in sales. His family has always supported him in developing and improving his work. He offers food products, dairy products, breads, cereals, drinks, canned food, candies, and more products to his customers.
 
Today, Yassin is requesting a loan to purchase merchandise to stock his shop in the hopes that this will increase his sales and, therefore, his income.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for resale

loans.name: Mazbut

texts.en:
R. Mazbut is 36 years old and married with 4 children. He has been a farmer for the last 10 years; farming is his passion. He practices both dairy farming and mixed crop farming. Mazbut says he has chosen farming as a career because his farm produce has a ready market. His challenge at the moment is that he is not fully utilizing all his land because he used up all his proceeds from the last harvest to pay his children's school fees and was not able to buy enough seeds and fertilizers. Mazbut is requesting a loan of $2500 USD to be able to plough the whole farm for the next planting season and to buy fertilizer and seeds.   
   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:  Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Gaibullo

texts.en:
Gaibullo is married and the father of 6 children. He is a farmer. Together with his children he grows potatoes, carrots and onions — work in which he  hopes to make progress and provide for his family. He wants to invest in his farm, expand his crop fields, and improve the quality of his products. Gaibullo knows that if he takes care of his land and works diligently he will reap excellent crops that will do better in the market.  He is asking for a loan to purchase the necessary seeds and fertilizer. Support this hard-working father so his effort is worthwhile!

loans.use: Purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Genalyn

texts.en:
Genalyn B. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old and widowed with three school-aged children. She runs a retail store selling seafood products  including fish and shrimp. She has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Genalyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Genalyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more fish to sell and working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Genalyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell and for working capital

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 40 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth has a business selling coconut oil in the local community. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Kev

texts.en: Mrs. S., 50, lives in the best territory of Kompong Tom province, Cambodia, where she has owned a plot of land since 1995. She grows vegetables, which she plants twice a year. She sells the matured crops to buyers who take them to sell retail at the market. S. is a good mother to her four school-aged children. Her husband works with her on the farm. Mrs. S. has a son who is unemployed. He wants to get a suitable job, but he needs money to pay for a service fee to have a job. This is why Mrs. S. has requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner, HKL.

loans.use: To pay a service fee for a job.

loans.name: Yakubjon

texts.en:
Yakubjon T. is dedicated to farming activities and has been engaged in this activity for 10 years. Presently he is the father of three children. Yakubjon must continue providing them with the conditions necessary for their scholastic development.

His reason for coming to IMON International is to obtain a loan with which he will buy seeds and fertilizers for his crops. Yakubjon and his family will benefit a lot from this loan, and so he is waiting for his request to be granted, and in this way he will have the financial capital to continue with his business in agriculture.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Abilio Jose Das Neves

texts.pt:
Abílio José Das Neves R., nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha, Fronteira com Suazilândia, a Oeste da Província do Maputo, tem 32 anos de idade vive maritalmente, é pai de 2 filhos com idades compreendidas entre 3 e 8 anos, o mais velho é que vai a escola. Fez a 7ª classe, não continuou devido a falta de condições, vive na casa própria não responsabiliza se por ninguem. 


Abílio nunca saiu do Distrito, vive maritalmente com sua esposa. E dono de uma oficina mecânica em sua casa, e conta com ajuda de dois empregados que auferem 2.000.00mt mensal por pessoa. Para aumentar a renda familiar com o fundo coletado ele consegue abrir um estabelecimento comercial onde vende produtos de primeira necessidade nomeadamente (feijão, arroz, amendoim, bolachas, farinhas), e alguns refrigerantes trabalhando das 7h as 20h e tendo de lucro 5.000.00mt a 6.000.00mt que aplica nas despesas da casa e na sua obra. Aproxima se a Hluvuku e Kiva solicitando um empréstimo para aumentar os produtos já existentes e satisfazer a necessidades dos clientes no período da peregrinação (cerimonia religiosa que se tem feito anualmente).


Este é o segundo empréstimo de Abílio na Hluvuku e primeiro com Kiva. O primeiro de 12.000.00mt foi usado para comprar insumos agrícolas para sua machamba, estes 15.000.00mt serão usados para aumentar o volume dos seus produtos e satisfazer a necessidade dos peregrinos. Esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para dar inicio da construção da sua capoeira.
texts.en:
Abílio José Das Neves R. was born in Namaacha District, near the Swaziland border, in western Maputo Province. He is 32 years old, is married, and has two children who are 3 and 8 years old. The eldest goes to school. Abílio finished seventh grade but did not continue because of financial problems. He lives in his own house and does not support anyone else. Abílio has never left this District and lives with his wife. He owns a mechanic's shop which is in his house, and he relies on the help of two employees who each receive 2,000 meticais per month. To increase his family's income, he used his savings to open a shop where he sells basic items, namely beans, rice, peanuts, crackers, flour and some refrigerated products. He works from 7:00 am until 8:00 pm and makes a profit of 5,000 to 6,000 meticais, which he uses for household expenses and for work. He approached Hluvuku and Kiva to ask for a loan to add to the products he now carries and meet his customers' needs during the time of pilgrimage (a religious ceremony that takes place annually). This is Abílio's second loan with Hluvuku and his first with Kiva. The first loan of 12,000 meticais was used to buy agricultural supplies for his machamba (a large garden or small field). These 15,000 meticais will be used to increase his inventory and meet the needs of the pilgrims. He is confident that he will pay off the loan ahead of schedule and ask for another to begin building a chicken coop.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, flour, oil, drinks, etc.

loans.name: Dante

texts.en:
Dante B. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 25 years old and single. To make a living Dante plants and harvests potatoes to sell. He has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

Dante joined HSPFI in 2010 to improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting his first loan, for 5000 PHP, which he will use to purchase fertilizers such as manure. He plans to use the additional to expand his business.

About HSPFI

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Sa

texts.en:
Sa Y., 56, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. She sells Chinese noodles and porridge for an income of about USD 4 per day. Her husband is a construction worker who earns USD 5 per day.

Y. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more supplements to expand her business of selling food. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more supplements to expand her food business.

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em S., 51, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. She is a housewife and her husband is a tuk-tuk driver who earns an income of USD 7 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a new tuk tuk. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

[S.'s husband appears in the photograph.]

loans.use: To buy a new tuk tuk.

loans.name: Oam

texts.en:
Oam H., 55, is widowed and resides with two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. She sells vegetables for an income of about USD 4 per day. Her daughter is a chef who earns an income of USD 3.5 per day.

H. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike to transport the vegetables to sell at the market. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport her vegetables to sell at the market

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and spare parts for motorcycles

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam S., 29, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. She raises pigs at home for an income of about USD 4 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike for her brother to commute to work in the town. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao S., 32, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. She is a housewife while her husband is a construction worker who earns an income of USD 8 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase construction materials to expand her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy construction materials to expand her husband's business.

loans.name: Chann

texts.en:
Mr. Chann P., 27 years old, is a local construction laborer earning $3 per day in a commune of Kompong Tom, a province of Cambodia. He is a single man who currently lives with his older father and other family members. They all have jobs at different fields.

Chann P. has requested a loan for the purpose of repairing the broken wooden wall of his existing house. The loan will provide a more comfortable living for this family.

loans.use: To repaire the broken wooden wall of an existing house.

loans.name: Sea

texts.en:
Sea M., 53, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. She is a housewife while her husband is a farmer who grows rice and earns an income of USD 4 per day.

M. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a plot of farmland to grow more rice. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland.

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Neang T., 50, is widowed and resides with her four children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, the most populated city in the country. She sells groceries and clothes for an income of about USD 7 per day.

T. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to buy more clothes to expand the current business. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Vong

texts.en:
Vong N., 45, is married and resides with her husband and a young child in Phnom Penh City, the most populated city in Cambodia. She sells shoes at a local market for an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver who earns an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses.

N. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to buy more shoes for resale. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy shoes for resale.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo C., 38, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Phnom Penh City, the most populated city in Cambodia. She is a civil service employee who earns an income of about USD 6 per day.

C. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

[C.'s husband appears in the photograph.]

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Wael

texts.en:
Wael is a 33-year-old married man from Lebanon. He has a fruit and vegetable shop. He sells all types of fruits and vegetables depending on the season. Wael has been in this business for two years and has been able to attract many customers in his neighborhood since he sells good quality products.

Wael is requesting a loan for the first time from Kiva partner Al Majmoua so that he can buy fruits and vegetables. This will help him become more competitive in the market.

In the future he plans to continue improving his work by purchasing and offering the best products and also purchasing more exotic fruits and vegetables depending on the season.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Hong

texts.en:
Hong N., 49, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Phnom Penh City, the most populated city in Cambodia. She sells food in front of her house for an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband is employed as an officer at the ministry of planning, earning an income of USD 4 per day to help cover the family expenses.

N. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to buy a motorbike for commuting to work. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Hang

texts.en:
Mrs. Hang S. is a coconut trader who lives in a small village in the province of Kompong Tom. She has another financial earner in her husband who is a fisherman. Hang S. and her husband are good parents who have four children: two are single, two are married.

Hang S. always picks coconuts directly from the trees and then delivers the coconuts using a cart to sell door-to-door around her community. Her son helps her to pick the coconuts.

Hang S. owns a small cart that is able to carry few coconuts. She wants to buy another cart which is a bigger one in order to replace the existing one. This is why she has requested a loan.

loans.use: To buy a bigger cart for transporting coconuts.

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Marthaline L., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Is Able. She is 35 years old, married and has four children who range from 4 to 19 years. She cares for two siblings. She is also a nursing student.

For 12 years, she has been selling palm oil at the Redlight Market in Paynesville, Liberia. She started selling with 1,500 Liberian Dollars and now has 20,000 Liberian dollars as working capital.

She plans to use her 12,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 53,000 Liberian Dollars group loan amount to buy more palm oil.

Her goal is to grow her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future. She describes herself as a God-fearing woman who likes to take good care of her children.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, group member Edith is inset at lower right because she was absent during interview.

loans.use: To buy more palm oil.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina A., 36, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Danilo A., a messenger, they are blessed with three children. Gina has been managing her own variety store for ten years now and she makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. 

Gina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. She is consistent in paying her dues because she has used the money she borrowed in the past to expand and improve her business. Her good repayment performance with her previous loans means she was able to borrow five times in CCT’s Cooperative. 

To ensure the future success of her business, Gina has applied for a loan of 14,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to the expanding business by buying additional items to be incorporated into her current product inventory.

Gina dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery items

loans.name: Sharifjon

texts.en:
56-year-old Sharifjon is a farmer and married with 4 children. He has been a member of IMON International in Tajikistan since last year and has used his loans to expand his farm. For more than 9 years, Sharifjon has been growing wheat, onions, and other crops on his land. With the loan he has recently applied for, Sharifjon intends to buy more seeds and fertilizer to invest in his crop. Sharifjon says he will use his experience to build a successful business and plans to hire at least two workers over the coming year.

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
George W., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Is Able. He is 67 years old, married and has 17 children who range from 6 to 38 years. He also cares for two siblings. He was only able to attend school through 7th grade due to financial difficulties.

For four years, he has been selling soap, candles, radio batteries, toothbrushes, toothpaste and powder in the Paynesville Community, Liberia. He sells in a friendly manner, which keeps customers returning.

He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan amount to purchase more radio batteries, soap, candles, toothpaste and toothbrushes. His goal is to grow his business and to continue to support his family.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Mrs. Long Y., 49, resides in Kompong Tom Province and earns a low income. She is a good and determined mother who has tried to feed her five children since they were young. One of them is now married; the remaining four are single. Her husband is a rice farmer. To pursue a daily revenue, Long Y. picks ripe fruits to sell at the local market. By doing this, she has the ability to generate formal income to help meet her family's needs. Long Y. is looking for capital to sustain her fruit business.

loans.use: To sustain her fruit business

loans.name: Altynai's Group

texts.en:
Altynai T., the leader of the group, breeds and fattens cattle. She has been doing this for 15 years, and when others in the family are available, they help her. Altynai is married to a social worker; she is 56 years old and has two children. The older son works in an automobile factory in Korea and the other just graduated from medical school. Altynai started her business buying two sheep with 3000 som (65.28$). Today she makes 2000 som (43.52$) per month. She has a plot where she can cultivate land and would like to increase her monthly salary, thus with the loan she plans to buy fertilizers and a variety of seeds.

Anar A. is the 39-year-old treasurer of the group. Her husband is a tractor driver, who often helps her farm, and she has three children. Her older son works in Russia, and the others are students. Anar is a farmer who has been plowing the land and breeding cattle for ten years. She makes 1500 som (32.64$) a month and her initial investment was 6500 som (141.95$). She would like to use the loan to purchase more livestock: chickens in particular.

Mahabat O., like the others in her group, is a farmer, but helps out in her husband’s family welding business. From her welding work, this 25-year-old was able to buy three goats and now she has eight. Her monthly profit is 1000 som (21.76$), and she plans to use the loan to purchase fertilizers for farming. Mahabat wants to increase the number of livestock and resell them to buy a vehicle.

Abdygapar A. has a 24-year-old son who works in Russia and a 22-year-old daughter who is a university student. He is a farmer and also provides transportation services. Abdygapar has been farming for 10 years. He started with an initial investment of 2400 som and cultivated one ton of potatoes, as well as buying two cows. Today, Abdygapar makes 6000 som (130.57$) per month and wishes to use the loan to buy fertilizers and a variety of seeds for farming.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and a variety of seeds

loans.name: Tweyambe Women's, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
B. Matia, aged 35, with a family of six children, operates a retail shop in Kyarutanga trading centre. There he trades in a variety of products commonly bought for domestic use.

Matia’s main drawback is that he has a limited variety of products in his shop that cannot satisfy his customers’ demand. Therefore, he is looking forward to increasing the stock in his business when he gets this loan and also to expanding into a wholesale shop in future. This will help him earn more revenue and sustain his daily-living needs.

Matia belongs to a group of members who insure each other in paying back the loan. They are on their 17th loan. Matia is standing in the back row raising his hand as group leader. The ones squatting with hands raised are also executive members of the group but were not interviewed.

loans.use: To buy more stock for his shop

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita C., 55, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Conrado C., a side car driver, and they are blessed with one child. Juanita makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing a canteen for quite some time now.

Juanita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Her good repayment performance with her previous loans means she was able to borrow eight times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business. 

To ensure the success of her business, Juanita would like to apply for a loan of 10,000 PHP. This will be used as a source of added capital for the expanding business, to buy raw ingredients needed for the canteen.

Juanita dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buying raw ingredients to continue canteen operation

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Mrs. Kim L. has a medium-sized stall where she raises a lot of female ducks to produce eggs for sale. She has had many years of experience feeding ducks, a skill she learned from her parents. Her husband is a village consultant and also assists her in raising ducks. The couple was married many years ago and they have five children. Two are now married and work in a garment factory, and the remaining three are single and attend school. Raising ducks is providing the family with a stable income, so Kim L. will be using the loan she has requested to buy many more ducks to raise for eggs.

loans.use: To buy female ducks to raise for eggs

loans.name: Miatta Group

texts.en:
Miatta S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Miatta Group. She is 45 years old, married and has five children who range from 10 to 27 years old. She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support.

For 29 years, she has been selling food stuffs like tomatoes, pepper, salt, onions and black pepper in Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She talks to her customers in a friendly manner, which keeps them returning. 

She plans to use her 12,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 54,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of pepper, onions and salt.

She wants to improve her business to the point where she can begin to import goods like slippers and clothing. Her goal is to continue to support her family so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more bags of pepper, onions and salt

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina V., 59, is making sure that she is able to provide for her family’s daily needs. Married to Reymondo V., the couple are blessed with three children. Cristina helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her business of buying and selling frozen meats for quite some time now. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

Cristina has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Her good repayment performance with her previous loans has enabled her to borrow ten times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she has used the money she has borrowed to expand and improve her business. To ensure the continued success of her business, Cristina is asking for a loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional frozen meats.

* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buying additional meats and frozen products to sell

loans.name: Gulumhan's Group

texts.en:
Gulumhan M. is the leader for this group loan. She is 50 and a widow. She has raised two sons and four daughters. The youngest daughter studies at school, while the others work in Russia. One daughter helps Gulumhan in breeding, fattening and reselling cattle, which she has been doing for 32 years. Through this business she earns 3000 soms (65.28$) per month, which has made it possible for her to repair her house and contribute some money to her son's wedding. Wth money received from this loan Gulumhan plans to purchase seeds and grow rice. In the future she wishes to contribute to her daughters' marriage.

Dilvarkan O., 42, is married. Her husband has a disability. Her fourteen-year-old son studies at school, and her six-year-old daughter takes care of her husband at home. Dilvarkan has been fattening and reselling cattle for 15 years, for a monthly profit of 3000 soms (65.28$). This has made it possible for her to build a house. Dilvarkan needs a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers to sow rice.

Maman K. is 71. His wife is a pensioner. They have nine daughters and a son. All the daughters are married and live in neighboring villages with their families. The son is a shepherd, and lives with the parents. Maman has been breeding and reselling cattle for 52 years. Through this business he makes 4000 soms (87$) a month. Maman wants to get a loan to purchase cattle, in order to resell it after fattening. 

Aisulu O. is the treasurer of the group. She is 32 and married. The husband works as a janitor in Russia. They have a daughter and a son, both at preschool age. Six years ago, with an initial investment of 15000 soms (326.44$), Aisulu bought a cow and a calf for breeding. Now she makes 3000 soms (65.28$) per month. With money received from this loan Aisulu wants to buy building materials in order to continue the construction of their house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society); Profit (to be profitable to grow further); and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan to deliver its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and grow rice

loans.name: Faithful Group

texts.en:
Amos G., shown holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Faithful. A senior student at a university, Amos is 32 years old, married and cares for one sibling. For eight years, he has been selling phone cards in the Parker Paint community outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He started his business with the limited funds he received while serving as a private security guard.

Amos plans to use his 15,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 42,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more phone cards, hoping to eventually expand the business and make more profit to be able to continue to support his family.

loans.use: To buy more phone cards.

loans.name: Progressive Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
38-year-old S. Joseph is a hard-grinding go-getter and father of three. He is now well-posted, in terms of experience, in his ten-year-old retail and boda-boda businesses (local commercial motorcycle transportation) which he concurrently operates in Terere, Mukono.

For the most part, it's Joseph’s retail business which has given him the financial ways and means to cater for all his children’s education and also to improve his family's welfare. The odds of future success in his retail enterprise have been rising in every passing year, ever since he took root. His enterprise and experience have both been playing in his favor.

At present, Joseph’s weekly generated profits are 100,000 shillings. With this loan, he wants to revamp his shop with an array of new retail merchandise and he also wants to improve his bod-boda business. Joseph also says that he gets additional revenue from fishing and he is happy about it.

loans.use: To purchase more items for his shop like sugar, salt, soap, etc.

loans.name: One Word Business Friends Group

texts.en:
Aloysius K., shown holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called One Word Business Friends. A 37-year-old single father of two children, 9 and 14 years old, Aloysius was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial constraints. Both of his children attend school.

For 14 years, Aloysius has been selling used clothes at the Redlight Market outside Monrovia, Liberia, a business he started with the meagre funds he received from working as a casual laborer at the Freeport of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 28,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more used clothes and hopes in the future to relocate his business to an ideal area where he can make more profit so as to continue to support his family.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes.

loans.name: Love Group

texts.en:
Mercy W., shown holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Love. A 52-year-old married mother of six children who range from 14 to 39 years old, she was not able to attend school due to poverty. All of her children are attending school.

For 25 years, Mercy has been selling charcoal, soap, sugar and cooking oil at the Redlight Market outside Monrovia, Liberia, a business she started with the limited funds she received from her husband and some family members.  Mercy plans to use her 8,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 40,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more charcoal, soap, sugar and cooking oil, hoping to grow her business and make more profit so as to continue to support her family.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal, soap, sugar and cooking oil.

loans.name: Empty Bags Sellers Group

texts.en:
James P., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "Empty Bags Sellers". He is 48 years old, married and has three children who range in age from 3 to 11 years. He cares for one sibling. All of his children are attending school.
