For three years, James has been selling empty bags at the Redlight Market in Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He started his business with 2,000 Liberian dollars (LRD) and now has 4,000 LRD as working capital. He plans to use his 5,000 LRD portion of this 25,000 LRD group loan to buy more empty bags. James describes himself as an elder with good character. He hopes to grow his business and move into the sale of general goods. He wants to make more profit, build a house and be able to continue to support his family.

loans.use: To buy more empty bags

loans.name: Tajy Poty Group

texts.es:
Para la formación el presente comité inicio mediante la iniciativa de y la invitacion de la Señora Cecilia Pico  del Barrio Fatima ya que ella Contacto con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en la Zona.

El comité se Denomina “Tajy Poty” están en el Séptimo Ciclo con 18 integrantes, es un grupo que se destaca en el barrio por ser muy unidas, solidarias y responsable entre ellas, las mismas possen un ahorro un fondo en común para cualquier necesidad que pueda sugir.

Una de las integrantes es la señora Zulli quien se dedica a la venta de ropa en un salon que tiene en su casa. Ella tiene 4 hijos en edad escolar y su marido es de profesion electricista y trabaja para una empresa aunque el señor trabaje y tenga sueldo fijo mensual el ingreso y resulte insuficiente para mantener a la familia es  por ello que la señora Zully realiza el maximo esfuerzo para trabajar y disminuer los gastos de la casa.

Solicita el préstamo para la compra sabanas y edredones para complementa su roperia.
texts.en:
The formation of this existing committee was the result of the initiative taken by Sra. Cecilia Pico, who lives in the neighborhood of Fatima. She contacted her neighbors and friends to invite them to start a local committee. The committee selected the name “Tajy Poty” and is starting its seventh loan cycle with 18 members. This group stands out in the neighborhood due to the unity and responsibility of its members. They contribute to a common savings fund to cover any needs that may arise. One of the members is Sra. Zully who sells clothing out of the living room in her house. She has four school age children and her husband works for a company as a professional electrician. His monthly fixed income is not enough to support their family, so Sra. Zully invests full effort into her work and tries to minimize their household expenses. She is requesting a loan to buy bed sheets and comforters to complement her clothing sales.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bed sheets & comforters

loans.name: Women United Group

texts.en:
Miatta K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Women United. She is 48 years old, married and has six children who range from 13 to 26 years old. She also cares for one sibling. All of her children are attending school.

For 25 years, she has been selling petroleum products (gas) in Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She started her business with 10,000 Liberian dollars and now has 70,000 Liberian dollars as working capital.

She plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more petroleum products (gas).

She hopes to expand her business and to make more profit to be able to continue supporting her family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Madam T. is inset at the lower right.

loans.use: To buy more petroleum products (gas)

loans.name: Fanta

texts.fr:
Né vers 1966 à San, Fatoumata B. s’est très vite intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère puisse qu’elle n’ a pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école. Mariée et mère de 7  enfants, Fatoumata vit chez son époux et leurs enfants  au quartier  Bagadadji  de la ville de San préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali) 
Elle est très sollicitée par ses nombreux clients pour la qualité de ses marchandises.   
Dans le souci de  mieux satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle  décida de faire recours à l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a trois  ans. Après  4 cycles de prêt solidaire elle est venue au prêt individuel. 
Elle est à son premier individuel et compte l’utiliser pour acheter journellement, 50kg de poissons  qui seront vendus sa clientèle composé  de femmes et d’hommes, en détail, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
Fatoumata espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 26 000 FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour rembourser l’échéance du prêt et utiliser  le reste pour payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants, acheter la nourriture et investir le reste dans d’autres activités de revenus.
texts.en:
Born in 1966 in San, Ms. Fatoumata B. did not have the chance to go to school. So she quickly became interested in revenue-generating businesses from her mother. Married and the mother of seven children, she lives with her husband and children in the Bagadadji district in San City, San Prefecture (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She is in high demand by her numerous customers for the quality of her merchandise. Concerned about better satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she decided to turn toward the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After four solidarity loan cycles, she came to individual loans. She is on her first individual loan and plans on using it to buy on a daily basis 50 kg of fish that will be sold to her customers, who are composed of women and men. She accepts cash and often credit for these retail sales. Fatoumata hopes to make a monthly profit of 26,000 francs CFA that she envisions using to make loan payments, to cover the schooling costs for her children, to buy food, and to reinvest the rest in other revenue activities.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fresh fish

loans.name: Celsa

texts.es:
La Señora Celsa  es casada,  tiene una pequeña despensa  en el barrio San Miguel,  la venta en la misma es gratificante ya que cuenta con una considerable cantidad de clientes y el ingreso es bastante satisfactorio.
Con la ayuda de su esposo  están  saliendo adelante con voluntad, trabajo y dedicación.
Con el trabajo y el buen manejo de su negocio hoy día se ha convertido en una microempresaria exitosa y en constante progreso.
Ha demostrado ser una persona responsable y honesta en sus compromisos sería conveniente brindarle todo el apoyo necesario.
En esta ocasión solicita el préstamo para la compra de fideos, arroz, azúcar, panificados, dulces, golosinas, yerba, enlatados.
texts.en:
Sra. Celsa is married and has a small store in the San Miguel neighborhood. She finds the retail business to be rewarding because she has a considerable number of customers and her income is satisfactory. With the help of her husband, she is able to move forward with determination, hard work, and dedication. By working and managing her business well, she has been able to develop into a successful businesswoman who makes constant progress. She has demonstrated that she is a responsible and honest person in all of her commitments.

Celsa would find it desirable to have all the necessary support. On this occasion, she is requesting a loan to buy noodles, rice, sugar, baked goods, sweets, candy, tea, and canned goods.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: De Los Santa

texts.es:
La  Sra. De Los Santa es casada, tiene cinco hijos,  tres   en edad escolar.
Ella  tiene una pequeña despensa  en el km 7 Ciudad Nueva, cuya venta cada vez más está en ascenso, generándole un buen ingreso es por ello que quiere construir un salon aparte para surtir mejor su negocio y solicita el préstsmo para la compra materiales de contrucción(ladrillos, cementos, tierra, pago de mano de obra) .

Con la ayuda de su esposo y toda la familia están  saliendo adelante con mucho sacrificio y esfuerzo.
Hoy día ella es una microempresaria exitosa con una clientela fiel y numerosa, debido a su amabilidad.
texts.en:
Sra. De Los Santa is married and has five children, three of whom are in school. She manages a small food pantry located at Km 7 in Ciudad Nueva. Her sales continue to increase every week, so she is able to generate a good income. She wants to build a separate room so that she can keep her business well-stocked. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to buy construction materials (bricks, cement, and sand) and pay for labor.

With the help of her husband and the rest of her family, De Los Santa has been able to move forward after much sacrifice and effort. Today she is a successful businesswoman with many loyal customers due to her kindness.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for materials & labor needed to build a separate room for her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cloth to sew more garments

loans.name: God's Grace Group

texts.en:
Mohammed A., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God's Grace. He is 25 years old, single and was only able to attend school through ninth grade due to financial difficulties.

For six years, he has been selling goods such as milk, sardines, batteries and soap at the Redlight Market in Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He started his business with funds his uncle gave him for school, but he had to do business for some years then go back to school.

He plans to use his 18,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 48,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more milk, soap, sardines and batteries. He describes himself as determined, honest and hard-working.

He hopes to improve his business and to go back to school, improving the standard of living of his family.

loans.use: To buy more milk, soap, sardines and batteries

loans.name: Kyabahuura Twetungure, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
It is now twelve years since N. Geralds started his farming adventure in Kyabahuura, Kazo. The married father of three is very aggressive and determined when it comes to business. He has since engaged himself in various farming practices including livestock.

Geralds’ main drawbacks include the bad weather conditions like drought which reduce his rate of production output compared to the input, and also the fluctuating prices. With this loan he is looking forward to buying seeds and hiring labour as he is set to prepare land for maize and bean planting. Gerald is very optimistic about getting more harvests and more revenue.

Geralds is the first on the right raising his hand, while the others on the left with their hands raised are the committee members.

loans.use: To buy seeds and pay for labor for planting

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more used clothes and salt

loans.name: Espiritu Santo Group

texts.es:
El comiteEspiritu Santo se formo mediante la invitación de la asesora y el deseo de las señoras de formar un grupo solidari para trabajar y progresar a fin de mejorar la calidad de vida  de sus familias. 
Una de la integrantes es la señora Juana quien se dedica a la venta de Joyas, ellaa sae unicio con esta actividad despues de formar parte del comité, y su forma der trabajo consiste en ofreser sus prendas a  conocido y amigos vendio en ocasiones a crédito o al contado. 
La señora Juana solicita el préstamo para la compra de mas joyas como pulcera, aros, gargantillas, cadenas y otros todosn oro y plata para contar con mayor variedad de productos para ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
The formation of the “Espirtu Santo” (Holy Spirit) Committee resulted from an invitation offered by an advisor. The women who joined wanted to start a solidarity group so that they could work together and progress toward improving the lives of their families.

One of the members is Sra. Juana who sells jewelry. She started her business after joining the committee. Her work consists of selling accessories to acquaintances and friends. Her sales are made by accepting cash or extending credit. Sra. Juana is requesting a loan to buy more jewelry such as bracelets, earrings, necklaces, chains, and other items made of gold and silver so that she can offer a greater variety of products to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase various articles of jewelry to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 24-year old single woman from Lebanon. She lives with her parents and four siblings. Two of her household members are also working to support the family. She has been running an educational tutoring business from her home since 2006. She specializes in education for elementary school students. Currently she has four students who come to her on a regular basis.

She is requesting a loan of $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. She plans to purchase new tables, a white board, and flipchart to help improve her work. This will be her first loan from Ameen. She estimates that the loan will help her increase her profits by 5%.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit: http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: to purchase new tables, a white board, and a flipchart

loans.name: God's Blessing Group

texts.en:
Sarah Z., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God's Blessing. She is 34 years old, single and has two children who are 4 and 9 years old. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial constraints and she cares for one sibling.

For three years, he has been selling salt, flour, cooking oil and sugar at the Redlight Market in Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She started her business with one bag of sugar and now is able to add flour, salt and cooking oil. She says insufficient cash to purchase more of the kinds of goods she sells is a major challenge to her business.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more sugar, flour, cooking oil and salt. She describes herself as a serviceable woman.

He hopes to grow her business and to continue to support her family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Brenda is inset at lower right.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, flour, cooking oil and salt

loans.name: Tibisay

texts.es:
A la orilla de la carretera del municipio de Palmar de Varela, ubicado al Oriente del departamento del Atlántico, vive Tibisay E. M., una muy joven mujer de 23 años que tiene su familia compuesta por el cónyuge e hijo de tres años de edad. Ahí tiene un pequeño almacén, donde compra  y vende  repuestos de bicicleta y con su esposo, y muchas veces su cuñado que está en temporadas de alto volumen de ventas,  presta  el servicio de mantenimiento y reparación de este medio de transporte ecológico que es muy usual en este municipio.

Como ella quiere ampliarse al mercado de mantenimiento y  reparación de motos, que su esposo y su cuñado conocen bien, está solicitando su primer crédito a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo  por valor de $1.000.000 con el comprará  mofles, rines y retrovisores para motos y además surtirá  su almacén con cadenas, estrellas, guayas y neumáticos para llantas de bicicletas.

Su meta es incluir su servicio de motos y fortalecerlo mas adelante con mucha tecnificación,  ahora su gran desafío es comprar su casa en otro sector,  porque como esta justamente al pie de la carretera   hay mucho ruido y  la contaminación  pudiera afectar a su familia, porque transitan muchos  vehículos que desde otras ciudades del país van a Palmar de Varela o a otras regiones de Colombia.
texts.en:
At the edge of the highway in the town of Palmar de Varela, located in eastern part of the Department of Atlántico, lives Tibisay Escoria M.. She is a young woman who is 23 years of age and has a family consisting of her husband and three year old child. Tibisay has a small shop where she sells bicycle parts with her husband and brother-in-law. This season they have had a high volume of sales. They also provide maintenance and repair services for this mode of ecological transportation which is very common in this area.

Since she wants to expand her market by providing motorcycle repair and maintenance services, which her husband and brother-in-law are familiar with, Tibisay is requesting her first loan from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo in the amount of 1,000,000 COP in order to buy motorcycle parts such as mufflers, tires, and mirrors as well as bicycle parts such as chains, cranks, chain guards, and inner tubes for tires.

Her goal is to begin providing motorcycle services and strengthen her business later on by acquiring more technical equipment. At the moment, her greatest challenge is buying a house in a different area because she currently lives near the highway where there is a lot of noise and pollution that could affect her family. Many vehicles from other cities pass through Palmar de Varela on their way to other regions within Colombia.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bicycle & motorcycle parts

loans.name: Kipkorir

texts.en:
Kipkorir is 25 years old. He is married and has two children, 1½ and 4 years old. His eldest child is currently attending school.

He is a dairy farmer from Litein town, in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for 5 years and has employed two people from the community. His main product is milk, which he sells to the Kenya Cooperative Creameries in Litein town. Kipkorir is also a cash crop farmer; he sells his tea to Kapkatet Tea Factory, which is managed by the Kenya Tea Development Authority. His major challenge in this business is poor milk prices, lack of enough dairy feed, expensive animal feed and artificial insemination services.
 
Kipkorir recently repaid a previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 40,000 KES, and has requested this new loan of 80,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a dairy cow of high quality which will produce enough milk and earn the family extra income to meet their needs. In the future, he would like to expand his land to enable him plant more feed and increase the number of his cows from the current 4 to 7.

Kipkorir is grateful to Juhudi for their good work and requests more funding for the future.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard is 28 years old and married with a one-year-old child. He is a farmer from Rift Valley, Kenya, near Litein town. He has been farming for two years and employs one person from his community. His main product is milk, which he sells to the Kenya Cooperative Creameries in Sotik town. He is also a mason and earns income from offering quarry services to the local market. His main challenge in farming is the fluctuation in milk prices and lack of proper transport to the market.
Bernard has requested this loan of 60,000 KES from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, after successfully completing a previous loan of 30,000 KES. This loan will enable him to acquire an extra dairy cow, which will increase his milk production and earn the family enough income to improve their standard of living. In future, he would like to increase the size of his dairy herd and build a dairy unit. He will request more funds in future.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 41 years old, married, and has four children aged between 9 months and 17 years old. Two of the children currently attend school.
Esther is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. She has been practising mixed farming for 12 years and has managed to employ 8 people on a casual basis. Her main products are bananas, milk, vegetables, maize and millet, all of which she sells to the local market. She also operates a retail shop in the same area.
Esther's major challenges in farming are exploitation by middlemen who buy at very low prices, lack of proper means of transport, and lack of storage facilities for her cereals. She has requested this loan from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, for 50,000 KES to purchase more cereals for sale. She intends to use part of this loan to expand her retail shop. The extra income from this loan will enable her to educate her children and build a house that will be an asset to the family. She appreciates the help given by Juhudi and requests more funding and training on business management.

loans.use: To restock her cereals shop

loans.name: Naom

texts.en:
Naom is 50 years old and a married mother of five children aged between 13 and 26 years old, all of whom are currently attending school.
Naom is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya where she has been farming for 30 years. She has managed to employ one person on a permanent basis and 15 casual laborers seasonally. Her main products are maize, milk, fish, beans and millet, which she sells to the local market and its outskirts. Her major challenges are transportation and lack of capital to restock her business.
Naom has requested this loan for 70,000 KES from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, to purchase more cereals to sell in Nairobi town. The income from this loan will enable her to educate her children and build a store, which will increase the family's assets. In future, she plans to acquire land in an urban center and build a store for her goods. She also plans to dig more fish ponds to boost her income. She is grateful and appeals for more help to eradicate poverty.

loans.use: To stock her cereals shop

loans.name: Nehemiah

texts.en:
Nehemiah is 46 years old, married, and has six children aged between 10 and 21 years old. All of the children are in education. Nehemiah is a mixed farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. He has been farming for 20 years and has one permanent employee. Over time, he has employed 18 casual laborers during planting, weeding and harvesting times. Nehemiah is also a school teacher. His main challenges in farming are the unpredictable weather conditions, poor prices for his produce, and crop diseases.
Recently, Nehemiah completed a loan from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, for 45,000 KES, which he used to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He has requested this loan of 70,000 KES to lease more land and grow bananas. He says that he has been able to see his children in high school and university through farming. In future, he would like to go large scale by leasing more land and growing bananas and maize. He is requesting more training on business management skills from Juhudi.

loans.use: To lease land for growing bananas

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 69 years old and married with five adult-aged children. She is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. Esther has been farming for over 40 years and has one permanent employee and five casual laborers. Her main products are maize, beans, tea, vegetables, milk and bananas, which she sells to the local market. Her biggest challenges in farming are lack of enough inputs (which affects her production) and poor storage facilities that leads to the destruction of her products.
She successfully completed a previous loan of 45,000 KES from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, which she used to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She has requested this loan for 70,000 KES to lease land and purchase farm inputs. The income from this loan will assist her in taking care of the four orphans under her care and sending her son to college. The family's nutrition will improve as well. Esther expects to expand her farming and production, especially bananas, on a large scale.

loans.use: To lease land and purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Sheba

texts.en:
Sheba is 45 years old and married with eight children, aged 11-25. Two of her children are currently attending school.

She is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya, where she has been farming for 25 years. Her main products are maize, milk, beans, millet and tea, which she sells to the local market and Kenya Tea Development Authority. 

Her major challenges are high production costs, lack of sufficient storage facilities and crop diseases like aflatoxin which affect her cereals.

She recently completed a previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 40,000 KES and has requested this loan in order to farm maize, beans and millet. The income from these products will assist in educating her children and improve their living standards since she will be able to build an iron-roofed house and move from her grass-thatched house.

She expects her business to grow in future and be able to produce more cereals for sale through leasing of land.

loans.use: To farm maize, beans and millet

loans.name: Simion

texts.en:
Simion is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. He is 45 years old, married and has 7 children, ages 10-35 years old. Three of the children are currently attending school. He has been farming for 12 years and over time has employed 12 people on a casual basis. His main products are maize, milk, beans, goats and millet which he sells to the local market. He also owns a retail shop and some rental houses in the area. His main challenges in farming are the poor prices offered by the middlemen (since he sells his goods wholesale) and lack of enough capital for expansion.

Simion has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 70,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) after having successfully completed a previous loan of 45,000 KES. He will use this loan to purchase an ox plough for farming and to increase his stock of cereals. The income from this loan will enable him to educate his children and build more rental houses that he can leave as a legacy for his children. Simion would also like to expand his retail shop and stock farm inputs for sale. He wishes to explore new and wider markets for his products. He is appealing for more help from Juhudi and, if possible, more training on agriculture production.

loans.use: To purchase an ox plough and expand his cereal busines.

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice is a 55-year-old widowed mother of six children ranging in age between 17-36 years old. Two of her children are still attending school.

She is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya where she has been farming for 33 years. Her main products are maize, beans, millet, bananas and vegetables which she sells to the local market and other retail businesses. She solely relies on the income from farming to meet the family's expenses. Her major challenge is lack of enough capital for expansion and high input prices during planting season.

She recently completed her previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 35,000 KES. She has requested this loan for 60,000 KES to expand her cereals and banana business. The income from this loan will enable her to educate her children and provide for her family. 

She expects to stock cereals on large scale in five years time.

loans.use: To expand her cereal and banana business.

loans.name: Maria Ines

texts.es: Maria Ines tiene 56 años, su actividad económica es la crianza y engorde de pollos para engorde. Hace más de 10 años que inicio esta actividad, pues no tenía suficiente ingresos para mantener a sus 6 hijos pues ella tenía que buscar la forma de mantenerlos, actualmente ellos trabajan de manera independiente, Maria inicio con pocos pollos a medida a transcurrido el tiempo es que ha logrado aumentar su producción. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo y poder realizar la compra de alimento para los pollos y acondicionar el local para que puedan tener más espacio.
texts.en:
Maria Ines is 56 years old and earns her living by raising chickens for fattening. She has been in this business for more than ten years. Since her income was not enough to support her six chidren, Maria had to find ways to make money. Her children now work independently. She started with a few chickens, but as time passed she was able to increase her production.

The loan she requested will be used as operating capital to buy feed for her chickens and renovate her chicken coop so that the birds will have more space.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase poultry feed & renovate a chicken coop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, cooking oil and meat

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her vegetable business.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina P. sells provisions in front of her house in Takoradi. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a welder. She has received junior high education. Faustina uses her income to help her husband with the general upkeep of their home. Faustina will use this loan to purchase more groceries to sell. Faustina plans to save the new profits from her expanded business to build a shop.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Jeronima Francisca

texts.es: Jerónima Francisca L. es una señora trabajadora, horrada, esforzada quien desde hace veinte años se dedica al comercio de artesanía la cual distribuye en los países centroamericanos (El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, Costa Rica y Panamá). Ella con el crédito compra mercadería con el propósito de seguir adelante.
texts.en:
Jerónima Francisca L. is a hardworking, honest, and courageous woman who has been selling handicrafts for twenty years. Her products are distributed to other countries in Central America including El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, Costa Rica, and Panama. Her loan will be used to buy merchandise so that she can move forward.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase handicrafts to sell

loans.name: Wilter

texts.en:
Wilter is 45 years old. She is married with five children, ages 18 to 30 years old. Two of the children are attending school.

She is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya where she has been farming for 15 years. Her products are milk, maize and tea which she sells to the local market and Kenya Tea Development Authority. She also buys and sells maize at the local market. Her main challenges are the poor transport network and lack of finances to do business at a higher level.

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 35,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. Through this loan she will be able to acquire a dairy cow that will increase her security and this will enable her access to bigger loans in the future. The extra income from this loan will enable her to educate and feed her family.

She is grateful to Kiva and Juhudi Kilimo for their loan and hopes to get more support in the future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 33 years old. He is married and has five children, ages 3-12. Four of the children are currently attending school.

He is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya where he has been farming for six years. He has employed four people from the community to help in his farm. His main products are jaggery (unrefined sugar) and maize, which he sells to retail shops. He is also a cash crop farmer and sells his tea to Kenya Tea Development Authority. 

His major challenges in farming are the changes in climatic conditions (especially floods that hamper transportation of his goods) and the middlemen who take advantage of farmers by buying products at a low price.

He has requested a loan of KES 35,000 from Juhudi Kilimo, which he will use to purchase and insure a dairy cow. Through this loan, he will be able to acquire a high quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for consumption and for sale. The extra income from this loan will help him educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase tables & furniture

loans.name: God's Purpose Group

texts.en:
Esther G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God's Purpose. She is 49 years old, married and has seven children who range from 18 to 34 years old. She was only able to attend school through fifth grade due to poverty. She cares for one sibling.

For 20 years, she has been selling pork and pig feet at the Redlight Market in Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She says insufficient cash to purchase more goods (pork and pig feet) is a major challenge to her business.

She plans to use her 5,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 25,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more pig feet and pork. She describes herself as an easygoing woman.

She hopes to improve her business and to continue to support her family so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more pig feet and pork

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is 35 years old. He is married and has seven children, ages 2½-16. All the children except the youngest one are attending school.

He is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya where he has been farming for 12 years. His main products are vegetables, bananas, and oranges, which he sells in the local market. He also makes ballast and knits sweaters.

His biggest challenges in farming are a lack of finances, a poor transport network, and the lack of an organized market for his products.

He has requested a loan of KES.40,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him acquire a dairy cow that will produce enough milk for consumption and for sale.

He hopes to take out larger loans in future so he can invest more in his business.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Workig capital

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 32 years old. He is married and has three children who are between the ages of three months and five years. Two of the children are attending school.

He is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. He has been farming for 10 years. His main products are bananas and maize, which he sells to the local market. He also runs a hotel business in the area and sells clothes to the local market.

His major challenges in farming are a lack of finances, a poor transport network, and natural disasters like hailstorms that destroy his crops.

He has requested a loan of KES 40,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable h1m acquire a dairy cow that will produce enough milk for both domestic consumption and for sale. In the future, he would like to expand his hotel business by offering more services.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Bertha Leonor

texts.es:
Doña Bertha es una mujer activa y trabajadora con el objetivo de poder ayudar  a su familia, trabaja en un hospital de la capital de Managua, como nutricionista aplique y me dieron la oportunidad ya que estudie para poder optar a mejores oportunidades y lograr apoyar  a mí hijo en el futuro. También vende productos nutricionales  para ayudarse con los ingresos, con estos financiamientos ha mejorado  su casa el cual esta contenta por las mejoras, su necesidad es poder construir su baño ya que es de zinc y desea cerrarlo bien para poder tener una mejor privacidad e higiene, tiene comprado arena, el cual comprara piedra, cemento, hierro para poder hacer la construcción. 

Sus planes es lograr mantener su trabajo ya que es su fuente fija de ingresos para poder seguir mejorando su casa, ya que le falta el piso, repellar paredes, pintar lo que es para ella de  mucha importancia para el bienestar de su familia.
texts.en:
Bertha is an active and hardworking woman whose goal is to be able to help her family. She works at a hospital in the capital, Managua, where she has a job as a nutritionist. “I applied and they gave me the job, since it is what I studied so that I could have better opportunities and be able to help my son in the future,” Bertha explains. She also sells nutritional products so that she can increase her income—this money has allowed her to make improvements to her home. She is happy with the improvements, but now she needs to construct a new bathroom, since her current bathroom is made of zinc, and she wants to enclose it in order to have better privacy and hygiene. Bertha has already purchased sand, and she will purchase stone, cement, and rebar so that she can proceed with the construction. Bertha’s plan is to keep working in her job, since it provides a steady source of income that allows her to continue improving her home. She still lacks a floor, and also needs to plaster and paint the walls. These improvements are very important for her family’s wellbeing.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing stone, rebar, and cement for constructing a bathroom, which she really needs.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To invest in their respective businesses, including grocery stores, plant sales, flower arrangements, hair salon, clothing sales and others.  They all want to improve their quality of life and provide a better future for their children.

loans.name: Elchin

texts.en: Elchin H. is a 24-year-old man who sells home products in the store he rents in Bilasuvar city. Elchin is married and has one son. Elchin dreams of building his own shop. He applied for a loan of 1000 AZN, which he will use to increase the number of products he sells.

loans.use: purchase more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Tamella

texts.en: Tamella Q. is a 44-year-old woman who sells cattle for meat production and makes milk products for her family. Usually Tamella sells cattle to the local butchers and restaurants. She has seven years of experience in this field. Tamella is married and has four children. She applied for a loan of 1000 AZN so she can purchase three calves.

loans.use: To buy three calves

loans.name: Manaf

texts.en: Manaf S. is a 44-year-old man who has been selling cattle for the last 20 years. He is married and has three sons who provide the meaning for his life. They help Manaf and his wife with cattle breeding. Manaf usually purchases young cattle and fattens and raises them. After several months, he sells them to the local butchers or takes them to the livestock bazaar, 30 minutes away from his village. Manaf applied for 1000 Azerbaijani manats to purchase three calves and fodder.

loans.use: To purchase three calves

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Sharifa

texts.en:
Sharifa K. is a 42-year-old woman who has more than twenty years of experience in poultry breeding. She breeds ducks, geese, turkey and chicken. Sharifa sells her poultry to local residents and, once every two months, she goes to the livestock bazaar and sells a significant amount there.

Sharifa is married and has two children. Her dream is to see them as independent adults with their own businesses. Sharifa has applied for a 600 AZN loan and will use it to purchase more poultry for breeding.

loans.use: purchase more poultry

loans.name: Vidadi

texts.en: Vidadi Z. is a 44-year-old merchant who sells different types of foods.  He has been running his small business since 2005. Vidadi is married and has 3 daughters. This store is the main financial source for Vidadi's family. He is also a musician and plays at most of the wedding parties in his city. Vidadi has a successful client history with AqroInvest, having already received one loan. He has now applied for a second loan of 1000 AZN, which he will use to purchase more foodstuffs for his store.

loans.use: to purchase more foodstuffs to increase income

loans.name: Akhmadaga

texts.en: Akhmadaga A. is a 57-year-old man who has been breeding cattle in the small village of Sabirabad since 1988. Akhmadaga is married and has four children who are grown adults. He sells cattle to the local butcher shops and residents. He has applied for a 1000 AZN loan to purchase two cattle and fodder. Akhmadaga has already successfully completed his first loan from AqroInvest through KIVA and he wants to state his appreciation to everyone who supported his business.

loans.use: to purchase two cattle and fodder

loans.name: Balgolan

texts.en: Balgolan A. is a 34-year-old merchant who has been selling cosmetics such as deodorants, lipsticks, shampoos, and perfumes in his rented shop for the last ten years. He is married and has one son. His business is the only financial source for his family and Balgolan does his best to develop it. He is a very polite person and always gives a discount to his permanent clients. He has applied for a 1000 AZN loan, his second loan from AqroInvest through KIVA, having successfully repaid the first loan on time.

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To operate businesses

loans.name: Gulnaz

texts.en: Gulnaz H. is a 55-year-old pharmacist who has been selling medicine in the local drug store in Sabirabad for the last 24 years. She is married and has three children. Gulnaz would like to increase her monthly turnover and purchase more expensive drugs as they are in high demand. She says many people cannot find medicine in Sabirabad and have to go to another city to buy expensive and necessary medicine. Her loan request is 1000 AZN.

loans.use: to purchase more expensive drugs

loans.name: Natiq

texts.en: Natiq B., 27, is a young and very successful businessman. He breeds cattle and sells them in the local bazaar. This is his primary business, but Natiq also works in the fire brigade. Although he went to work every day, his salary wasn’t enough to cover his family's basic needs, and so Natiq started cattle breeding in 2009. Usually he buys small calves, fattens and raises them, and after several months sells them in the livestock bazaar. Natiq would like to purchase two cattle and fodder, which will allow him to increase his profit and improve life for his wife and son.

loans.use: to purchase two cattle and fodder

loans.name: Ismayil

texts.en: Ismayil  H. is a 43-year-old farmer who has bred cattle for the last ten years. He is married and has three children. Ismayil buys baby calves, fattens them and then sells them to local butchers and residents. Once every two months, he brings the animals to the livestock bazaar. Ismayil is requesting a loan of 800 AZN to purchase three baby calves to raise and sell by August for the highest price.

loans.use: to purchase three calves

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To operate businesses.

loans.name: Rafiq

texts.en: Rafiq A. is a 56-year-old farmer who has bred cattle very successfully for the last 11 years. He is married and has three children who actively help him and his wife. His work requires a lot of effort because Rafiq spends most of the time in the open air, regardless of season. He raises cattle and sells them to the local butchers. He has applied for a loan of 1000 AZN to purchase three calves and increase his profit.

loans.use: to purchase three calves

loans.name: Ashraf

texts.en: Ashraf M., 48, is an experienced and very successful cattle breeder who has lived and raised cattle in Bilasuvar since 2002. Ashraf is married and has three children. He is a master of construction and builds houses on demand, but it happens very seldom, so Ashraf's main financial income comes from cattle breeding. He needs 1000 AZN to purchase two calves and fodder. This will allow him to sell more calves, increase his income and improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase two calves and fodder

loans.name: Teyyub

texts.en: Teyyub M. is a 50-year-old cattle breeder, married with three children. Teyyub has 14 years of experience in cattle breeding. He considers himself a successful businessman because during the lean years, he gained a number of permanent clients from the butcher shops, who always buy cattle from him. Teyyub has applied for a 500 AZN loan to purchase one milking cow and to start selling milk and milk products.

loans.use: to buy one milking cow

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gulmirza

texts.en: Gulmirza A. is a 47-year-old man who sells cattle in the small village of Saatli. He started his business when he was 20, thanks to the experience that his father provided for him. Gulmirza is married and has three children. He applied for an 800 Azerbaijani manat (AZN) loan to purchase one cow and fodder.

loans.use: To purchase one cow and fodder

loans.name: Alaskar

texts.en: Alaskar R., age 57, breeds sheep in the small village of Saatli. He has four children. Alaskar breeds sheep because it is very profitable: mutton is a highly popular item among people in Azerbaijan. He has applied for a loan in the amount of 1,000 AZN in order to purchase more lambs, fatten them, and sell them in several months for a higher price. He generally sells his sheep to the local butcher shops and in the livestock bazaar.

loans.use: To buy 20 lambs

loans.name: Nadir

texts.en: Nadir Q., age 50, sells men's clothes and shoes. He has 10 years of experience in this business. His business has been successful and has allowed him to build his own shop several years ago. Nadir is a very friendly man who is always polite to his customers. He is married and has two children. He is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,000 AZN to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy new seasonal clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Sahib

texts.en: Sahib A., 36 years old, has his own barber shop, which he opened in 2009. He is married and has three children. He is a professional barber who used to work in a large barber shop before deciding to open his own business. Sahib has applied for a loan in the amount of 1,000 AZN in order to purchase more barber's tools and to improve his working conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more barber's tools and improve his working conditions

loans.name: Angela Agustina

texts.es: Ángela Agustina tiene 46 años, su actividad es la venta de comida y además brinda el servicio de procesador de oro. Hace más de 3 años se ha dedicado en la venta de comida, actividad que realiza en su propia casa, preparando los más deliciosos almuerzos para sus clientes. Le gusta mucho su trabajo, ya que puede disponer de su tiempo y eso la hace sentirse independiente y con esperanzas de darle un futuro mejor a su familia. Su mayor anhelo es poner un negocio más estable como un restaurante, pero por el momento se siente tranquila con su trabajo. Ella solicita este financiamiento destinado para capital de trabajo granos básicos, gaseosas, verduras y frutas.
texts.en:
Angela Agustina is 46 years old and for more than 3 years has run a small business from her home, preparing delicious lunches for her customers. Angela likes her work. She can control her schedule and it makes her feel more independent, and she feels hopeful that she can provide a better future for her family. Her greatest dream is to have a more stable business like a proper restaurant, but for the moment she is content with her work. Angela is requesting this loan to invest in her business and purchase grains, sodas, vegetable and fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase grain, sodas, fruits and vegetables for her small business

loans.name: Elbrus

texts.en: Elbrus A., age 55, is a trader who sells fruits and vegetables. For a year, he has been able to sell these items in his own store. He sells different kinds of seasonal vegetables and fruits. He is married and has two sons. Elbrus would like to increase the number and variety of products he sells in order to increase his profit. He has applied for a loan in the amount of 900 AZN.

loans.use: To purchase more seasonal food items to sell

loans.name: Yakhya

texts.en: Yakhya K., age 56, has been a seller of different kinds of food items in his own shop for the last eight years. He is married and has three children. Yakhya started his business because his pension wasn’t enough to cover basic family needs. The monthly income from his business is 150 AZN. Now Yakhya needs a loan in the amount of 800 AZN in order to purchase more merchandise for his shop so that he can increase his turnover income.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for sale in his shop

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Yadigar

texts.en: Yadigar I., 39 years old, has been a breeder of cows, calves, and bulls for the last 10 years. Thanks to the very first loan he received from Kiva, he was able to develop his business. He now has five cows, three calves, and two bulls. Generally, he breeds cows for milk and milk products, and calves for meat production. Milk products are always very popular and can be expensive, which is why Yadigar decided to breed them. Now he would like to purchase more cattle and for this purpose he has applied for a loan in the amount of 1,000 AZN.

loans.use: To buy two calves and fodder

loans.name: Nuevo Renacer Group

texts.es: El grupo “Nuevo Renacer” esta representado por la señora Gaby y conformada por 13 miembros en su integridad mujeres, mismas que han demostrado ser muy responsables y trabajadoras. La señora Gaby es casada tiene 2 hijos, son niños en edad escolar, la señora se dedica a la venta de dulces y empanadas en una cancha deportiva concurrida del barrio, las expectativas de Gaby es tener un kiosco en el barrio para tener ventas más continuas y así obtener mas ingresos, ella vive en alquiler por el momento y los planes que tiene con su esposo  es mejorar su negocio y ahorrar para tener una casa propia, también desea poder darles una educación mas adecuada a sus hijos para que lleguen a obtener una profesión a futuro, ella requiere el préstamo para invertir en la construcción de un puesto fijo y para incrementar sus mercadería. El resto de las socias del grupo se dedican a diferentes actividades como la venta de ropa, venta de comida, zapatos, hamacas, empanadas y asaditos. El grupo en general tiene  experiencia en los negocios que desempeñan y es por esta razón que son conocidos en las ferias de su barrio donde venden sus productos. Si bien la competencia en general es bastante alta, el grupo cuenta con experiencia y también con clientes fijos que reconocen su trabajo y demandan sus servicios y productos, por otra parte es importante el entusiasmo que ponen a lo que hacen. El presente crédito será utilizado como capital de operaciones, con la compra de mercadería, insumos y herramientas de trabajo. La expectativa que tiene el grupo es de seguir trabajando para crecer u mejorar sus ingresos para darles a sus familias una mejor calidad de vida. El banco tiene bastante experiencia crediticia ya que no es la primera vez que obtienen un crédito, el presente por ejemplo es su tercer ciclo en los cuales han demostrado responsabilidad, unidad y ganas de trabajar para salir adelante.
texts.en:
The "Nuevo Renacer" ("New Dawn") group is represented by Gaby and made up of 13 women who are responsible and hard-working. Gaby is married and has two children, who are of school age. She sells sweets and empanadas in a sports field popular in the neighborhood. Gaby would like to have a kiosk in the neighborhood so she can sell more regularly and thereby increase her income. At the moment, she is renter, and she and her husband plan to improve their business and save up for their own house. She also wants to give her children a better education so that they can have a profession in the future. She is asking for a loan to invest in the construction of a stand and to increase her merchandise. The other members of the group are involved in a variety of activities, including selling clothing, food, hammocks, savory pastries, and grilled food. The group as a whole is experienced in the activities in which it is involved, and for this reason, it is well-known at the neighborhood markets where it sells its products. Within this competitive environment, the group already has regular customers who are familiar with its work and ask for its services and products. The group is enthusiastic about what it does. This credit will be used as working capital for buying merchandise, raw materials, and work tools. The group expects to keep working in order to grow and to increase its profits so its members can give their families a better quality of life. Their bank is already familiar with this group--it is not their first loan, but their third funding cycle. They have previously demonstrated that they are responsible, united, and hard-working enough to look to the future.

Translated from Spanish by Ross Forman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Latif

texts.en: Latif A. is a 60-year-old man who started breeding cattle six years ago when he retired from his work. Latif is married and has five children. He is working as a driver, but his main source of income comes from livestock breeding. He sells milk and milk products to the local people. Now he would like to purchase cattle and fatten them for meat production. He has potential customers who keep butcher shops and meat is in high demand. Latif applied for a loan of 1,000 AZN to purchase three baby calves.

loans.use: To purchase three baby calves

loans.name: Zahir

texts.en: Zahir A. is 37 years old. He is a farmer who has been breeding sheep for the last three years. He sells them to the local butchers. Zahir is married and has two children. He lives and works in Imishli city where the main livestock bazaar is located so he does not need to go a long way to sell his sheep. He usually sells sheep to the local butchers and to the restaurants, as mutton is very popular among Azerbaijani people. Zahir is going to develop his business. He applied for a loan of 1,000 AZN in order to purchase 14 sheep and fodder.

loans.use: To purchase sheep and fodder

loans.name: Shamil

texts.en: Shamil A. is a 29-year-old trader who sells home products as well as some cookies and sweets. He has five years of experience in this field. Shamil is married and has a son. His main clients are women because they usually come to buy something for their house. Shamil applied for a loan of 1000 AZN and will purchase more merchandise to sell.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise to sell

loans.name: Trabajando Juntas Group

texts.es: El grupo “Trabajando Juntas” esta representado por el señor Dennis Sergio y conformado por 10 miembros, 3 varones y 9 mujeres son socios que viven en el mismo barrio y se conocen muy bien por lo que confían en sus integrantes. El señor Denis Sergio tiene dos hijos es casado y vive con su familia en su casa propia, el negocio al cual se dedica es la venta de repuestos de movilidades y trabaja con las líneas de transporte de la zona, el desea poder agrandar su negocio y requiere de mayor mercadería para lograrlo es por esta razón que requiere del préstamo ya que eso le permitirá mejorar su negocio y poder mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia. El resto del grupo se dedica a diferentes actividades como la venta de productos de belleza por catalogo, atención de  puntos de comunicación, chofer de transporte de pasajeros, costurera de prendas de vestir, atención de almacén, venta de comida, transcriptora de tesis y ensamblador de computadora. La competencia existe, pero las socias tienen mucha experiencia en el rubro y saben como salir adelante por lo que no es un factor importante para ellas. El destino del financiamiento será para la compra de insumos, mercadería y para la reparación de sus herramientas de trabajo. Todas las socias van cumpliendo su segundo ciclo por lo que tienen mucha experiencia en grupos solidarios, en cada ciclo han demostrado ser responsables en sus pagos, unidos y solidarios con su grupo saliendo adelante cada día mas.
texts.en:
The Trabajando Juntas ("Working Together") group is represented by Dennis Sergio and has 10 members, 3 men and 9 women. The members live in the same neighbourhood and know each other very well; they trust each other. Denis Sergio is married, has two children and lives with his family in their own home. He sells spare parts for vehicles, and works with the local transport lines. He wants to be able to expand his business and needs more merchandise to do so. For this reason, he is requesting this loan, which will help him to improve his business and his family's quality of life. The other group members have different occupations, such as: cosmetics sales through catalogues; communications services; driving; clothes making; storekeeping; food sales; thesis transcribing; and computer assembly. There is competition, but it is not an important factor: the group members have a lot of experience in the industry and know how to get ahead. The loan will be used for the purchase of materials and merchandise, and for repairs to work tools. All of the group members are in their second loan cycle, and thus they have much experience working in groups. In each cycle they have been responsible with their repayments, united and supportive of their group, getting ahead more and more each day.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 49 ans, 6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Sontiguila, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de condiments, et d’articles divers.
Ces femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur premier prêt solidaire.     
FANTA D. du groupe Benkadi compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une importante quantité d’articles divers.
Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises avec les commerçants du village de Nangola et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Nangola et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the group Benkadi are all married and average 49 years of age and six children all living in traditional extended families in the village of Sontiguila, Dioïla Prefecture, Region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another through ties of kinship, and they do commerce in condiments and a variety of items. The women in this group are on their first solidarity loan. FANTA D., of the group Benkadi, plans on using her loan to buy a significant quantity of various items. She gets her supplies from merchants in the village of Nangola and accepts cash or credit from a customer base composed of women and men. She sells locally at the Nangola market and at surrounding fairs. She plans on making an average monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA that will be used for day-to-day family expenses. The rest will be reinvested in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria S. prepares cassava dough and bags of water for sale at Takoradi. She is married and has four children. She has no educational background. Victoria uses her income to help her husband provide food, clothing and shelter for the family. Victoria will use the loan to purchase more cassava to prepare cassava dough for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Victoria plans to support her home.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Maria Esmeralda

texts.es:
Doña Maria es una mujer trabajadora, lleva más de veinte años en el comercio, su negocio es la venta de ropa, toallas, cosmético y la venta de piñata, que logro invertir con dinero propio de sus ahorros, provenientes de su trabajo.
La ropa que vende la compra en el mercado oriental a bajo precio por docena, y luego la revende, y le queda su ganancia, vende ropa variada para dama, niños, perfume al contado y al crédito de quincena. 
Para ella no es fácil ya que le resulta cansado a veces, también las ventas se ponen bajas, y se desequilibra ya que tiene más gastos que entrada de ingresos y aun apoya  a sus nietas, lo que es preocupante.
Con esta solicitud invertirá en cosmético y ropa ya que tiene poca,  y desea aumentar las ventas como la captación de clientes. Para mejorar su negocio
texts.en:
Maria is a very hard-working woman. She has been in business for over twenty years. She sells clothing, towels, cosmetics, and piñatas that she was able to invest in with her own money saved from working. She buys the clothing to sell in an Oriental market where she buys it at low prices by the dozen. She then resells it for profit. She sells clothing for women and children, as well as perfume, for cash or on two week's credit. It is not always easy for her and sometimes it is tiring. Sometimes when sales are low it is upsetting as she can have more expenses than income. This is worrying because she also supports her granddaughters. With this loan she will invest in more cosmetics and clothing that she now has very little of as she would like to increase sales and retain more customers to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Anna Ruby Waxham Blackwell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetic products and clothing to increase sales.

loans.name: San Luis De Huancapi Group

texts.es:
La señora Sonia pertenence al Banco Comunal San Luis de Huancapi, las socias son del Distrito de Huancapi, Provincia de Víctor Fajardo, el distrito se ubica a 3 horas de la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Las socias realizan diversos negocios como Cafetín escolar, tienda de abarrotes, venta de comida, venta de frutas y verduras, compra y venta de animales menores y mayores y  cereales.
Sonia desempeña el cargo de auxiliar de tesorería, conviviente, tiene 2 hijos, Sonia tiene un Cafetín Escolar, en un inicio vendía golosinas en las calles, llevaba en una fuente a campeonatos, fiestas y hoy en día tiene su propio negocio como es el cafetín escolar en el colegio Basilio Auqui, sus productos los adquiere en Ayacucho a veces en Huancapi y los vende en el cafetín, fiestas y campeonatos, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su  esposo  y sus hijos. Su préstamo será invertido para  la compra de golosinas  y surtir su cafetín el otro porcentaje para abrir un bar en Huancapi. Los sueños de Sonia son que  sus  hijos sean profesionales, y  tener un local propio para bienestar de su familia.
texts.en:
Sonia belongs to the communal bank "San Luis de Huancapi." The members are from the Huancapi district in Víctor Fajardo province, located 3 hours from the city of Ayacucho. The members have a variety of businesses such as: school cafe, grocery store, food sales, fruit and vegetable sales, the purchase and sale of small and large animals, and cereals. Sonia performs the role of assistant treasurer. She lives with a partner and has 2 children. Sonia has a school cafe. She started out selling candy in the streets; this became a source of income as she started selling her products at sporting events and other celebrations. Today she has her own business, which is a school cafe in the Basilio Auqui school. She gets her products in Ayacucho and at times in Huancapi, and sells them in the cafe and at festivals and sporting events. Her husband and children help her with the business. Her loan will be invested in the purchase of candy and other items to restock her cafe, and a portion of the loan will be used to open a bar in Huancapi. Sonia dreams of having her children become professionals, and having her own store for the wellbeing of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy candy and items to restock her cafe, and another portion to open a bar in Huancapi

loans.name: Ronieri

texts.en:
After gaining valuable experience working for someone else, Ronieri knew he was ready to open his own business. Based on his understanding of the retail perfume business and his talent for working with the public, he knew he could run a successful perfume store.  He even knew where he wanted to open his store - in a kiosk at a mall.  But this Brazilian native wanted to be smart about financing his business.

Ronieri could have used credit cards to finance the purchase of his new kiosk and his initial inventory, but he was well aware of the high interest rate he'd have to pay.  So he contacted a government loan program and began their loan application process.  Unfortunately, they weren't used to dealing with a smaller retail start-up business, and asked for mountains of paperwork and documentation.  Ronieri was getting frustrated by the time and effort required to borrow money.

Then he decided to contact ACCION USA.  Since he had so much of his paperwork already in order, his loan approval was quite quick.  He set-up his kiosk and has already hired part-time help.  Ronieri is hoping, one day, to expand into a storefront in the same mall.  When he does, he hopes to have another positive experience working with ACCION USA to get his financing.

About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA: 

Have you ever thought about how the new café on your corner and the delivery service that brings the fresh baked goods acquired the financial resources to start their business? Chances are, they drummed up support from their friends and family, dipped into their personal savings, used a high-interest credit card, or all of the above. An estimated 10 million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis.” Microfinance institutions, like ACCION USA, support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly-priced capital and business education. 

 

Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild our economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. As unemployment rises in the U.S., more and more people are turning to self-employment and start-up enterprises as a way to take control of their economic futures and provide employment opportunities in their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: To purchase new inventory

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 44 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Fatiana, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de poisson frais, de condiments et de l’arachide.
Ces femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des poissons frais, des condiments et de l’arachide.                   
MAÏMOUNA D. qui est un membre du groupe compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des condiments alimentaires.
Elle s’approvisionne en condiments le plus généralement à Nangola et environnants et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Nangola et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 12 500F CFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi group, all married, are on the average 44 years old and have three children; all of them live in traditional extended families in the Fatiana village, Dioïla Prefecture, Koulikoro Region (the second administrative region of Mali). They know each other through family ties; their line of business is selling fresh fish, condiments and peanuts. The women of the Benkadi group are on their first group loan, which will be used to purchase fresh fish, condiments and peanuts. Maimouna D., one of the group members, plans to use her loan to purchase food condiments. She generally stocks up in Nangola and surrounding areas and sells her goods out of her home, at the Nangola market and the markets nearby, for cash or on credit, to a customer base composed of women and men. She plans to achieve an average monthly income of 12,500 West African Francs, which will be used towards everyday family expenses, and the rest reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing condiments [for resale]

loans.name: Angelina Del Carmen

texts.es: Angelina Del Carmen tiene 31 años, su actividad es la venta y elaboración de repostería. Hace más de 4 años, pues anteriormente sus productos compraba sus productos para venderlos, cuando se caso con su esposo quien es panadero  de profesión comenzaron a elaborar ellos mismos los productos, así fue que decidieron juntos empezar este negocio. El financiamiento que solicita actualmente es para la compra de materia prima que es necesaria para sus productos. El deseo de ella es establecer una panadearía muy grande.
texts.en:
Angelina Del Carmen is 31 years old, her activity is the making and selling of pastries and has been in the business for more than four years. She used to resell bakery products but once she got married with a baker by profession, they began to make their own products and decided to start this business together. The loan requested will be invested in the purchase of ingredients needed for their products. Her desire is to establish a large bakery

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 34 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Sompiya, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce du bétail, du savon, du pain et le tricotage de la laine.
Ces femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du bétail, du savon kabakourouni, de l’arachide, de tissu et de la laine.
DJELIKA S. du groupe Benkadi compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des tissus et de la laine.
Elle s’approvisionne en tissus et laine avec les commerçants de Wakoro (commune du village de Sompiya) et effectue la vente de ses produits finis sur place et dans les environnants de Sompiya, au comptant, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi group are all married and average 34 years of age and two children. They all live in extended traditional families in Sompiya, Dioïla Prefecture, in Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through bonds of kinship, and sell cattle, soap, bread, and knit wool. The women of the Benkadi group are seeking their first solidarity loan (group loan), to be used to buy cattle, "kabakourouni" soap (a locally produced soap), peanuts, fabrics, and wool. DJELIKA S., one of the members of the group, intends to use her loan to buy fabrics and wool. She gets her supplies of fabrics and wool from merchants in Wakoro (part of the Sompiya village), and sells her manufactured products in Sompiya and in the surroundings, for cash, to a clientele comprising mostly women. She expects to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 10'000 (ca US$ 20), to be used for the daily expenses of the family. The remainder will be reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics and wool

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Danaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 37 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Fatiana, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de condiments, de gâteaux, d’arachide et de poissons frais.
Ces femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des condiments alimentaires, de l’arachide, des sacs de farine de blé et des poissons.                   
FATOUMATA D. du groupe Danaya (qui est en T-SHEET jaune) compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter de la farine de blé.
Elle s’approvisionne en farine de blé avec les commerçants de Nangola, après transformation en gâteaux, elle effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Nangola et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000F CFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Danaya group are all married, are an average of 37 years old, have two children and live in traditional extended families in the village of Fatiana in the Dioïla prefecture, in the Koulikoro region (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other through family ties and are in the business of selling condiments, cakes, peanuts and fresh fish. The women of the Danaya group are on their first joint loan which will be used to buy condiments, peanuts, sacs of wheat flour, and fish. Fatouma D. of the Danaya group (in the yellow t-shirt) plans to use her loan to buy wheat flour. She gets her supplies of wheat flour from the traders in Nangola. After making it into cakes, she sells them from her home, at the market of Nangola, and in nearby markets, for cash and on credit, to a clientele of men and women. She plans to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 CFA which will be used to meet the daily expenses of her family and the rest will be reinvested her business.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy wheat flour

loans.name: Charlotte Asi

texts.en:
Charlotte Asi D. sells bags of rice from her storehouse at Abura. Her loan will be used to buy additional bags of rice to distribute to her customers. She hopes to use the new profits she is hoping to generate as a result of the loan to expand her business.

Charlotte has been through junior high school. She is a single parent of four children and single-handedly takes care of her family.

loans.use: To buy additional bags of rice

loans.name: Luz Del Transito

texts.es: Luz del Transito tiene 36 años, su actividad económica es la venta de ropa. Tiene 2 hijos que son menores de edad y están a su cargo. Ella inicio este negocio hace 5 años, por lo que se le presento un problema de salud con el último embarazo, pues es necesaria otra fuente de ingresos necesaria a su familia. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de materia prima como pantalones, camisas, faldas, ropa interior y trajes. Su deseo es mejorar las condiciones de de su familia.
texts.en:
Luz del Transito is 36 years old and is in the clothing sale business. She has two sons who are minors and depend on her. She started this business five years ago, since she had a health problem with her pregnancy and needed another source of income for her family. The loan requested will be invested in the purchase of pants, shirts, skirts, underwear and suits. Her desire is to improve the living conditions of her family

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Danaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Sompiya, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de bétail, de savon, d’arachide et d’articles divers.
Ces femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du bétail, du savon kabakourouni et de l’arachide et beaucoup d’articles divers.
AWA C. du groupe Danaya compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, du bétail  pour le revendre.
Elle s’approvisionne en bétail  le plus généralement sur place et effectue sa vente sur place, dans le village de Sompiya, au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Danaya group are all married, are an average of 41 years old, have three children and live in traditional extended families in Sompiya, in the Dioïla prefecture in the region of Koulikoro (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other through family ties and are in the business of selling livestock, soap, peanuts and various other items. The women of the Danaya group are on their first joint loan which will be used to buy livestock, Kabakourouni soap (a locally made soap), peanuts and numerous other items. Awa C. of the Danaya group plans to use her loan to buy livestock and to resell it. She usually gets her supplies of livestock locally and makes her sales in the village of Sompiya, for cash, to a clientele of men and women. She plans to make an average monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA which will be used to meet daily family expenses and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy livestock

loans.name: María Romilia

texts.es: María Romilia M. de 60 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Soyapango, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador. María es una señora muy responsable y trabajadora la cual vive junto a sus dos nietos, una niña de 11 años de edad y un niño de 10 años de edad, los cuales están al completo cuidado de María, y por quienes debe de velar por que tengan un mejor futuro y un presente en el cual cuenten con todo lo necesario para vivir de una forma saludable y feliz. La señora María se dedica a la venta de ropa para damas, así mismo vende zapatos y sandalias, y vende ropa para embarazadas.
