loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita A., 46, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She, a single mother, makes sure that she is earning well so that her family can have a better life. She has been into her food-vending business for quite some time now.

Teresita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Her good repayment performance with her previous loans means she was able to borrow four times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business. 

To ensure the success of her business, Teresita would like to apply for a loan of 8,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying raw meats and ingredients to continue operation of her business.

Teresita dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can buy her own house and lot in the future.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more meats and raw ingredients to continue production of her business

loans.name: Aishabubu's Group

texts.en: Aishabubu A. is the leader of this group. She is 58 and her husband is a farmer. She has raised ten children: six daughters and four sons. Most of them are working, except for the three youngest daughters who are students. The youngest son lives with his parents and helps them with housework. In order to make money, Aishabubu sells 5-6 liters of milk a day (at 7 soms per liter). After receiving the land in 1996, she and her husband began farming. They started with the initial investment of 3,000 soms (approximately 65 USD) and now they earn 1,000 soms (approximately 22 USD) per month. With money received from the loan she plans to purchase seventy liters of fuel, which is needed for the sowing process. Indira A. is 26 and is married to a farmer. They have a six-year-old daughter and a four-year-old son. The daughter studies at school. In order to make money, Indira sells 10-12 liters of milk a day. They are also preparing to pasteurize the milk in the summer season. She and her husband have been doing this for ten years. They started with the initial investment of 5,000 soms (approximately 108 USD) and now they earn 1,000 soms per month. Indira wants to get a loan to purchase a bull, and to resell it after fattening. Gulai A. is 56 and her husband is farmer. They have four daughters and two sons. All of the children are married and live separately from their parents. Gulai would like to use the money from the loan to make a gift to her son. She wants to give him money so that he can pay for his ten-year high school reunion dinner. Kiyal T. is 30 and has four sons and a daughter. Two sons study at school while the others are still too young. In order to make money, Kiyal sells 8-9 liters of milk per day. Fifteen years ago, after finishing university, Kiyal's husband began to keep bees. He started this business activity with the initial investment of 5,000 soms. In this way he makes 1,500 soms (approximately 32 USD) per month. With money received from the loan, they want to purchase the best variety of bees in order to improve the quality of their honey. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase 70 liters of fuel which is needed for sowing

Her good repayment performance with her previous loans means she was able to borrow four times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more raw meats and ingredients for her business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita A., 51, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Rodrigo A., a businessman, they are blessed with five children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing a clothing and curtain store while having a direct-selling business as a sideline. She sells a popular brands of cosmetics.

Teresita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues. She used the money that she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more quantities and designs of clothing to replenish her current inventory. She also will invest some of the loan to do advance orders on her cosmetics direct-selling line.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide her children with further education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: Towards buying more quantities and designs of clothing inventory and advance orders on her cosmetics direct selling line.

loans.name: Salimahon's Group

texts.en:
Salimahon K. is the leader of her group. She is 49 and a widow. Salimahon has raised two sons. The older son is 22; he manufactures bricks and sells them. In this way he makes 10000 soms (217.62$) per month. The younger son is 21; he studies at university. When he has free time, he helps Salimahon with housework. Several years ago with the initial investment of 6000 soms (130.57$), Salimahon began to grow rice and sell it. In this way she makes 3000 soms (65.28$) per month. This profit made it possible for her to purchase furniture and household appliances. With money received from the loan, Salimahon will purchase 150 kg of seeds and 100 kg of fertilizers, which are needed for the sowing process. In the future she plans to build a new house for her son.

Mubarahon K. is the treasurer of the group, she is 45. Her husband works as a private driver. in this job he earns 5000 soms (108.81$) per month. A 22 year old son is a bread baker and his monthly income is 5000 soms (108.81$). Mubarahon's daughter is 20. she takes orders and sews dresses. In this job she earns 2000 soms (43.52$) per month. Mubarahon grows rice and sells it. She started doing this 9 years ago, with the initial investment of 10000 soms (217.62$), and now she makes 4000 soms (87$) per month. She wants to get a loan to purchase fuel, seeds and fertilizers which are needed for the sowing process.

Dilfuzahon K. is 24. Her husband manufactures bricks and sells them. The income from this business is 10000 soms (217.62$) per month.  Dilfuzahon grows rice and tobacco. She started this business 3 years ago, with the initial investment of 8000 soms (174.1$). Now she makes 3000 soms (65.28$) per month. With money received from the loa, she will purchase two sheep for breeding. In the future, Dilfuzahon wants to open a grocery store.

Oydinahon T. is 26. Her husband is a bus driver. He earns 4000 soms (87$) per month. He also helps Oydinahon to sow and harvest rice and tobacco. They stated to grow tobacco five years ago. The initial investment in this business activity was 12000 soms (261.15$) and now they make 3000(65.28$) - 4000 soms (87$) per month. This profit made it possible for Oydinahon to purchase a vehicle and furniture. She needs a loan to purchase 100 kg of seeds and 50 kg of fertilizers for sowing wheat. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase 150 kg of seeds and 100 kg of fertilizers, which are needed for the sowing process.

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia C. is from the town of Banga. She is 46 years old, married and has 8 school-aged children. She is described as kind and helpful. Amalia is involved in farming and hog-raising. She plants rice crops and sells her harvest at the market. She also grows pigs for fattening. Amalia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years already.

Amalia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Amalia has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Amalia is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. She will also purchase feed for her pigs. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Amalia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees her children and supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Safari Group

texts.en:
Meet J. K. and the Safari Group.  J. is 48 years old, married and has four daughters.  J. has run a charcoal business for two years.  

Charcoal is important in Tanzania, because it is used for cooking in almost every home and restaurant.  J. leaves Dar Es Salaam to travel to the countryside, where he spends 5-6 days making charcoal from trees that he harvests.  He returns to the city with his product and sells it to wholesale and retail buyers.  

J. paid back his previous two loans from Tujijenge Tanzania, and will use this loan to expand his business.  He wants to hire more laborers to help him produce the charcoal, which will allow him to organize up to 15 sacks per trip.  He currently yields around ten sacks.  This should increase his profit, which is currently 320,000 Tsh (around $228) per month.  The extra profit will help J. support his children, and he hopes to reinvest and continue growing his business.

J. is the president of the Safari Group.  The name means "Journey" in Kiswahili.  The group's members will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan.

In the photo, J. is seated in the front row.

loans.use: Producing and selling more charcoal.

loans.name: Rina

texts.en:
Rina J. is currently in the business of selling clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes to sell. Rina is 33 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

texts.en:
In business, striking a first impression chord with your prospective or existing customers is one sure way of ensuring not only short-term but also long-term success. This is exactly the philosophy that 41-year-old K. Edward has used for the last five years to establish a niche for his business selling produce in Nalukolongo, Mityana.

This affably welcoming married father of three now reckons his long-term success is on the horizon, given the short-term hurdles he has overcome and the reciprocal relationship he has with his clients. This common cause he shares with his clients has enabled his business to make strides. This is manifested in the 280,000 shillings he makes monthly.

All of Edward’s three children and two dependents are in school. With this loan, Edward wants to buy more produce like maize, groundnuts (peanuts) and beans.

loans.name: Aïssatou

texts.fr: S. Aïssatou est née le 19 Novembre 1966 et est mariée à AKONDO Jerry. Le couple a deux enfants, et six enfants à leurs charges. Tous leurs enfants sont scolarisés. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Aïssatou s'est installée avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Gbégamey à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique. Le couple se partage ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Pour assurer ses différents besoins, Aïssatou mène comme activité la vente d'igname pilé à Allada. C'est dans le Nord du Bénin que Aïssatou s'approvisionne. Aïssatou a dix ans d'expérience dans l'exercice de cette activité et a déjà obtenu trois crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Dans le but de rehausser le niveau de son activité et d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaire, Aïssatou sollicite un quatrième prêt, afin de mieux faire face aux exigences de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Aissatou Seibou was born November 19, 1966 and is married to Jerry Akondo. The couple have two children and have six other children in their care. All of their children attend school .For the past 10 years Aissatou has lived with her husband and children in the Gbegarney neighborhood of Allada, in the Atlantic region of Benin. The couple work together to meet the family's needs. To meet their different needs, Aissatou sells ground sweet potato. She buys her supplies in the northern part of Benin. She has 10 years of experience in this business and has already completed three loans with ALIDe, loans that have been successfully repaid. In order to grow her business and increase her income Aissatouo is requested her fourth loan to better meet the needs of her clients.

loans.name: Evelyne

texts.fr: D. M. Evelyne est née le 07 Janvier 1952 à Parakou, au Nord du Bénin. Mariée à YANGO Henry, Evelyne est mère D. trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Cependant, aucun des enfants n'est à sa charge. Evelyne vit seule et assure seule ses différentes charges. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Evelyne s'est installée au quartier Allomey à  Allada, dans le département D. l'Atlantique. Depuis cinq ans environs, Evelyne vend des glaces et des sucettes à Allada. D. façon secondaire, Evelyne vend également des bijoux. Evelyne achète ses produits à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Evelyne est une ancienne cliente D. ALIDé, qui avait obtenu trois crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Evelyne désire élever le niveau D. son activité et surtout renforcer son activité D. vente D. bijoux pour mieux répondre à la demanD. nombreuse D. sa clientèle. C'est donc pour agrandir son activité D. vente D. bijoux et se faire plus D. revenus, que Evelyne sollicite un quatrième prêt.
texts.en:
Evelyne D. M. was born on January 7, 1952 in Parakou, in the North of Benin. She is married to Henry Yango and is the mother of three children, all of whom go to school. However, none of the children are dependent on her. Evelyne lives by herself and supports herself independently. About a dozen years ago, she moved to the Allomey district in Allada, in the Atlantic Prefecture of Benin. She has been selling ice cream and soft drinks in Allada for about five years. As a secondary business activity, she also sells jewelry. She purchases her goods in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Evelyne has already been a client of ALIDé in the past: she had obtained three loans, all of which were duly repaid. Evelyne would like to expand her business and, first of all, to build up her jewelry in order to better respond to customer demand. In order to expand her jewelry sales and increase her income, Evelyne is seeking a fourth loan.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to expand her handphone shop.

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn B. is from the town of Banga. She is 23 years old, is married, and has a 3-year-old child.

Jenelyn owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jenelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional piglets and feeds. This loan will be her first from CEVI.

Jenelyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets and feeds

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn M., from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, is 40 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a business providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 20 years, she earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Evelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC, Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase materials needed to provide service. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Temps De La Grace Plus Group

texts.en:
“Temps de la Grace” is a group of 27 owners of small businesses chaired by Pululu. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva to grow their businesses. Pululu sells soft drinks and cakes, a business she started in 2006 with $30. A hardworking woman who has demonstrated effective organizational and management skills in her enterprise, Pululu is a loyal client of the MFI HOPE RDC who has already received 11 loans, all repaid in a timely manner.

Pululu is planning to use her next loan to increase the stock of her goods by buying 10 crates of soft drinks and 4 cartons of eggs in order to meet the high demand of her customers. Confident in her business, she knows how to attract and maintain customers by offering what they need and like. She is also diplomatic when she talks with her clients. Pululu’s long term plan is to open a clothing shop.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods for resale

loans.name: Lani

texts.en:
Lani A. is a 40-year-old married woman from the village of Tagoloan Misamis Oriental in the Philippines. Lani has 3 school-age children. To earn a living, Lani owns and operates a business venture in the food sector by making and selling food. More specifically, her primary source of income is derived from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Lani has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2009, Lani joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. As a result, she is now able to engage in business activies and to improve her standard of living. Notably, Lani has successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to prepare her food items for sale. Lani is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 8,000 PHP ($175), which will be used to expand her business. This loan would be the second loan taken out by Lani from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and it reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business

loans.name: Solo E Nekesa Joyce Group

texts.en:
Joyce N. is a 37-year-old, married woman with two children. In addition, she looks after four dependents, all of whom are school-age children.

To earn a living, Joyce works in the produce sector. She has been engaged in this line of business for ten years. She is now seeking a loan to purchase produce, including peas, ground nuts, and beans, for re-sale purposes. She is determined to stock more produce and to thereby expand her business. She explains that she is a hard-working businesswoman whose dream is to prosper and to construct her own house.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional produce (e.g., peas, nuts, and beans)

loans.name: Carolino

texts.en:
Mr. Carolino R. is from the barangay of Labuyo, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. He is 49 years-old. Carolino is married to Dulcineta, his business partner and  they are blessed with two children who are both studying in college. To make a living, they sell chemicals wholesale and retail and most specifically “hypo” (calcium hypochlorite) and chlorine to be used for cleaning, disinfecting and for anti-stain. They’ve had this business for ten years  and earn approximately 2,600 PHP a month from this buy and sell activity. 

 In 2009, Carolino joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carolino is now requesting a second loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stocks of hypo for their business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of his family especially in meeting their basic needs and savings for future use especially for the children’s education and loan repayments.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Jocelyn is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 12,000 PHP ($275), which will be used to purchase seedlings and fertilizers such as manure. Lourdes joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Lourdes from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients, but also savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Nilufar's Group

texts.en:
Nilufar O. is the leader of this group and she is 35 years old. To make some money, her husband went to work in Russia. Nilufar has two daughters and a son. All of them study at school. Two years ago with an initial investment of 1200 soms, Nilufar started to sell potatoes and cherries.  She made good money and from that moment, Nilufar began to sell fruits and vegetables. Now she makes 5000 soms per month. With this profit, she was able to save money to repair the house and purchase a TV and DVD player. Nilufar wants to get a loan to purchase different fruits and vegetables in order to resell them and make a profit. In the future, she plans to stabilize her business, to pay a dowry for her daughters and build a sauna.

Umidahon S. is 35. Her husband is a farmer. She has three sons who are currently students. Twelve years ago with an initial investment of 1800 soms, Umidahon bought a calf and started breeding cattle. In this way, she makes 2500 soms per month. Now she wants to get a loan to purchase a bull, which will be resold after fattening. In the future, Umidahon would like to open a kiosk near her house.

Sayorahon R. is 28. Her husband works as a constructor and they have two sons, who are in kindergarten. Sayorahon works in a barbershop. With money received from the loan, she plans to purchase cement and other building materials in order to continue repairing the house.

Nafisahon S. is 26. In order to make some money, her husband went to work in Russia. They have a daughter and a son; both are currently in preschool. Nafisahon breeds, fattens and resells cattle and poultry. In this way, she makes 3000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Nafisahon wants to purchase a bull-calf and resell it after fattening. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan which delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.name: God's Favor Group

texts.en:
Ethel C., who is holding the sign in the photo, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God's Favor. She is 38 years old and married with two children, who are 23 and 24 years old. She was only able to attend school through 11th grade due to financial difficulties.

For 10 years, she has been selling cassava at the Red Light Market in Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. 

She plans to use her 7,000-Liberian-dollar portion of this 33,000-Liberian-dollar group loan to buy more cassava. She describes herself as hard working. Her dream is to grow her business and to continue to support her family so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Marie is in the inset photo at lower right because she was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more cassava

loans.name: Gaëlle Francine Amélévi

texts.en: Gaëlle is 32 years old. She owns a general store where she sells some food products, home products, and beauty products. She’s had her store since 2007. Her husband also owns a business and the two of them have 2 children. She has requested her first loan from WAGES for 250,000 CFA. She would like to purchase detergent, various beauty products, milk and oil.

loans.use: To purchase products to sell

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita T., already widowed at 45, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is blessed with a child from her marriage, and she makes sure that she earns well so that her family can have a better life. She has been managing her own eatery while overseeing her variety store and video rental business.

Amelita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she has used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the future success of her business, Amelita has applied for a PHP 9,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying raw ingredients needed for her recipes. She also will invest some of the loan to purchase groceries for the variety store.

She dreams that she will have her own stall so she won’t have to rent a place where she will sell her products.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her recipes and purchase grocery inventory

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia T., 51, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Fidel T., they are blessed with seven children. She has been managing her own variety store while also having a direct selling business on the side. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. 

Leticia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. She is consistent in paying her dues because she has used the money she borrowed in the past to expand and improve her variety store and direct selling business. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. 

To ensure the future success of her business, Leticia has applied for a PHP 9,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries needed to replenish her current product inventory. She will also invest a portion of the loan to do advance orders on her direct selling line.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also hopes that she will be able to renovate her house with all her hard work on her business.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries to replenish current inventory

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
Emelyn M. is from the village of Iniawon, Kadingilan Bukidnon. She is 32 years old and married with 1 infant-aged child. To make a living, Emelyn owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of her income comes primarily from cooking and selling grilled chicken and pork barbecue in the local community. Emelyn has been engaged in her business for over 1 year  and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid her most recent loan of 7,000 PHP which was used to purchase raw chicken and pork meat and to build up levels of working capital. Emelyn has now requested a new loan, her third with HSPFI, for 10,000 PHP to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Akossiwa Sitsofe

texts.en: Akossiwa runs an internet café. She is 42 years old, single and is raising one child. To improve her family's income, she opened her internet café in 2007. She has requested a loan from WAGES for 400,000 CFA to purchase four computers for her business. This is her second loan from WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase computers

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana H., 35, is making sure that her family members have enough to fulfill their daily needs. She is married to Joseph H., a taxi driver, and the couple is blessed with three children. Ana helps her husband earn a living so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own ice cream business while selling sticky rice cakes as a sideline.

Ana has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends the group's weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow several times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is able to pay her dues consistently because she used her previous loans to expand and improve her ice cream and sticky rice business.

To ensure the success of her business, Ana would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This will be used as added capital for her expanding business so that she can buy ingredients needed to continue production of her sticky rice cakes. She also will invest some of the loan to purchase more quantities of ice cream to replenish her current stock.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she and her family will have a comfortable and well -off life.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet weekly. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for sticky rice cakes

Juanita has been engaged in her business for more than 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Juanita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juanita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Juanita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: People Of Faith Group

texts.en:
Annie C., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called People Of Faith. A 28-year-old single mother of two children, 8 and 10 years old, she was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficulties.

For five years, Annie has been selling soap, candles and detergents at the Redlight Market in Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more soap, candles and detergents. Describing herself as hardworking, her dream is to grow her business and to continue to support her family so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Koisee is inset at lower right because he was absent during the interview.

For 3 years, he has been selling phone cards and petroleum products (gas) in Gardnesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He started his business with 500 Liberian Dollars that his mother gave him.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon M., 46, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Roberto M., a businessman, and they are blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn money so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own handicraft business while also selling L.P.G. fuel and mineral water in containers.

Corazon has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a loan of PHP 15,000. This amount will be used as added capital for her expanding business, enabling her to buy more products to be incorporated into her current product inventories.

loans.name: Dédé Amivi

texts.en:
This woman is 31 years old. She is married to a sailor and they have one child together.

She has been working as a hairdresser since 2009. In order to diversify her profits and satisfy her customers, she has also decided to sell some beauty products and cosmetics. She has requested a loan of 150,000 CFA from WAGES in order to purchase more cosmetics and other products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa B. is from the village of Sampagar, Damulog Bukidnon. She is 46 years old. Elsa is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Elsa owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling vegetables in the local community. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Elsa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase more vegetables to sell and as working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elsa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: God Is In Control Group

texts.en:
Mariah Q., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Is In Control. She is 41 years old, married, with five children who range from 5 to 23 years old. All of her children are attending school. She is also a nurse. 

For 3 years, She has been selling charcoal and soap in Gardnesville Market, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She started her business with 5,000 Liberian Dollars she took as a loan from a saving club.

She plans to use her 7,500 Liberian Dollars portion of this 34,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more charcoal and soap.

Her dream is to grow his business, make a profit, save, and be able to go to college so that she can have a better future.

A photo of group member Diana is inset at lower right because she was absent during interview.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and soap

loans.name: Kokou Akpé

He has requested a loan from WAGES of 500,000 West African CFA francs to purchase 150 cartons of various different hardware products to sell in his shop.

loans.name: Germelina

texts.en:
Germelina S. is from the village of Old Damulog, Damulog Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Germelina is married and has six adult children. Germelina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Germelina has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Germelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 7,000 PHP and was used purchase additional products to sell.

Germelina is requesting her third loan from HSPFI, this one for 10,000 PHP, which will be used to to expand the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita O., 52, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Eugenio O., a driver, they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn money so that their family can have a better life.  She has been overseeing operations of their van for quite some time now.

Mercedita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 19,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying the franchise license needed to legally continue operations of her van.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She dreams that they will be successful someday.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en:
Anahit S. is married and a mother of three. She and her husband currently live with their son and one grandchild, whose parents have gone to Russia to find jobs to support their family. 

Anahit has been managing her “lavash” (traditional Armenian flat bread) bakery to support her family. Her bread has become very popular, and she is now planning to expand her production to offer various bread types. 

This resourceful and energetic mother is the main source of income for her family. Anahit has applied for a $3000 loan.

Anahit is hopeful that her business will grow enough that her daughter and son-in-law can return from Russia to reunite with their child and help her at the bakery.

loans.use: To purchase a larger oven and mixer and wholesale flour

She makes sure that she helps her husband earn money so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own direct selling business for quite some time now.

Teresita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. loans.name: Ntara Multipurpose, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Hardworking T. Patrick, aged 38 years, operates a certain vocational school in Ntara, Ibanda, where he is head teacher. This school started three years ago and has since been accessed by many students due to its set academic standards.

This loan will help Patrick in the purchase of furniture for the school like desks and chairs, so as to improve the standard of the school. He is very optimistic of making it grow into the best institution, not only in his region, but in Uganda.

Patrick belongs to a group of members who insure each other in paying back the loan and this is the first time that Patrick is seeking a loan from Pearl.

Patrick is in a light blue shirt on the far right and is raising his hand. He is the one interviewed. The others with hands raised are committee members of the group.

loans.use: To buy furniture for his school

Geraldine has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. loans.name: Hernán

texts.es:
El Hernán R. es de profesión comerciante, está casado con la señora Feliciana Zorrilla con quien tiene cuatro hijos, dos mayores y dos menores, todos están domiciliados en el Kilómetro 7 Barrio Ciudad Nueva de Ciudad del Este, los mismos se dedican a la compra y venta de ropas, más específicamente de lencerías y abrigos, lo realizan en la misma zona distribuyendo en su propio rodado y también lo realizan en el vecino país de Argentina.
Se iniciaron en la actividad con créditos que solicitaron a la Fundación Paraguaya demostrando puntualidad en todos sus pagos, se tratan de personas emprendedoras y con visión de crecimiento.
En esta ocasión solicitan el préstamo para la compra de maderas para tirantes que están necesitando para terminar la casa.
texts.en:
Hernán R. is a merchant. He is married to Mrs. Feliciana Zorrilla and they have four children together, two who are adults and two who are minors. They all live at Kilometer 7, Ciudad Nueva neighborhood in Ciudad del Este. They buy and sell clothing, specifically lingerie and coats. They do this in the same area, distributing nearby and in the neighboring country of Argentina. They began this activity with loans they applied for fron the Fundación Paraguaya and they have demonstrated punctuality with all of their payments. They are enterprising people with visions of growth. On this occasion, they are asking for the loan to purchase wood for strips they need to finish their house.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wood

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina T. is from the village of New Campostela, Damulog Bukidnon. She is 53 years old, married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Cristina owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling coconut shell charcoal in the local community. Cristina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2009, Cristina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Cristina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase more coconut shells and working capital. Cristina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Cristina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Cresenciana

texts.en:
Cresenciana O., 49, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Antonio O., an operator, they are blessed with six children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn income so that their family can have a better life. To that end, she has been managing her own variety store, while renting out some apartment rooms. She also sells native rice cakes on the side.

Cresenciana has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. Cresenciana is able to be consistent in paying her dues because she used the loan money to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of additional capital to aid in buying groceries needed to replenish her varitey store's inventory. She will also invest some of the loan to purchase raw ingredients needed for her rice cakes. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina helps to support her family with a small business - she sells socks and women’s hosiery at a busy market in Melitopol, Ukraine. She and her husband, Michail, have two sons. Irina started her business 12 years ago, about a year after her second son was born. The business has been an important source of income for the family. Currently, Irina makes around 4,500 UAH in net profit per month. 

Irina has been a great client of Nadiya Ukraine and has been able to take out several loans that have helped with the development of her business. This time Irina has requested a loan of 10,000 UAH to help purchase additional inventory. She hopes to receive additional income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory.

texts.en:

This amount will be used as a source of additional capital to buy raw materials and supplies needed for her business. She dreams that her business will continue to grow. Nelia wants to be able to buy her own place where she can run her business and sell her products.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buying raw materials and supplies needed for rug-making.

loans.name: Abla Alaba

texts.en: Abla Alaba was born in 1956. She is married to a teacher and they have 3 children. Abla Alaba makes bread, yams, and other traditional Togolaise food that she sells from her stall outside her home. She has requested a loan of 200,000 CFA to purchase yams, oil, and other products she uses to make her cuisine.

loans.use: To purchase yams, oil, and other products.

Eugenia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative. loans.name: Akabare Tukwatanise Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
Having ventured into the business of cattle keeping, M. Josephine has no regrets. It being part of her culture, commonly carried out in western Uganda where people own large heads of cattle, 60-year-old Josephine has benefited a lot from her farming business. She sells milk, ghee (clarified butter) and also some cows for beef as they are some of the products she gets from her farming business.

Josephine’s motive to acquire this loan is to help her buy sprays for her cattle to kill ticks and also to buy de-worming medicine to treat against diseases that affect her cattle. This will help her increase production as well as increase revenue.

loans.use: To purchase sprays and de-worming medicine for her cattle

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila S., 46, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Gregorio S., she is blessed in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store while renting out some apartment rooms.

Mila has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 34,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying items needed to replenish stocks in her variety store. She will be buying groceries, toiletries and beverages.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying  groceries, toiletries and beverages for resale

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian K. is currently in the business of selling maize and sorghum at her store and is requesting a loan to stock bags of maize flour to sell.  Lilian is 43 years old and is widowed.   She has 5 children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her store.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock bags of maize flour to sell

loans.name: Hugo Ramón

texts.es:
El Sr. Hugo  es soltero y vive aún  con sus padres.
Tiene su local de trabajo en el domicilio de sus padres. 
El consiguió con mucho sacrificio y esfuerzo todo lo que tiene.
Con la ayuda de sus padres y toda la familia montó para su propia herrería, en la cual consigue trabajos que le proporcionan buen ingreso y satisfacción por parte de los clientes.
Él trabaja en forma ambulante obteniendo así más clientes, con su eficacia y dedicación, ya que lleva sus herramientas para realizar su labor en los domicilios de sus clientes.
Ha demostrado ser una persona responsable y honesta en sus compromisos, por lo que necesita el apoyo de nuestra institución para la compra de hierro que esta necesitando para los pedidos  que tiene.
texts.en:
Hugo is single and lives with his parents. His workshop is located in their home. He has earned all he has through sacrifice and hard work. With the help of his parents and family, he started his own blacksmith shop, and completes jobs that bring a good income for him as well as satisfaction for his customers. He works on the move to get more clients with his effectiveness and dedication, carrying his tools with him so he can work right in his clients' homes. He has shown himself to be a responsible, honest person in his commitments. He needs the help of this institution to purchase the iron he needs to fill his orders.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase iron

texts.en:

She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Gertruda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. loans.name: Kisakye Women's Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
A firm belief that she cannot fail in any business undertaking has always been 33-year-old S. Cissy’s winning trump card. With this kind of attribute and self-worth, this married mother of two has won her spurs in her retail shop enterprise, which she has operated for the past four years in Kafunta, Lugazi.

The business experience Cissy wields began with a two-year farming business that she later dispensed with. Since then the retail business has been her invaluable and settled means of subsistence. Her place of vantage in this business has been made doubly sure over the last four years by her good customer relationship skills.

Cissy’s future prospects are very rosy. She has made profitable use of her time spent operating her business. In a month, she reveals, she makes profits totaling up to 250,000 shillings. She also ekes out other side profits operating a taxi.

With this loan, Cissy wants to purchase more retail items for her shop like soap, sugar and salt.

loans.use: The purchase of more items for her store like sugar, soap, cooking oil and rice

She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. Marlyn has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying advance orders of cosmetics, etc. from her direct sales line

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice E. P  is currently in the business of selling beans and maize flour at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of beans and pulses (lentils).  Joice is 43 years old and is widowed.   She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to secure a house for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of beans and pulses (lentils)
